content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Short game, but tons of fun. The weapons are some of the most unique I've ever come across, and are worth the purchase of the game. The game itself is narrow and linear, with awesome graphics (DX11) and decent voice-acting. Get it on sale and get ready for a fun 10 or so hours. Installed size on hard drive (all DLC): 9 GBThis time around, we are playing as Darius Mason, son of Jake Mason (from the film Red Faction: Origins), and grandson of Alec Mason (Red Faction: Guerrilla). The terraformer has been destroyed, driving all of Mars' human residents underground. But even deeper inside the Mars crust lies an alien threat. If that sounds Red Faction: Armageddon has ventured into B-movie / game territory, you'd be right. It's a linear shooter, with some fantastic weapons (magnet gun! though the Napalm Laser is another favorite) and decent atmosphere and graphics. While I suppose much of Armageddon has been done before, it's done well here. So well that I was disappointed when the game ended that there wasn't more to it. If you're looking for more to do after finishing the single-player campaign but don't want to play through the campaign again, there are two additional modes available. Ruin mode (destroy the environment) is a lot of fun: destroy the environment as fast as possible. You'll be able to use whatever weapons you've unlocked in the main campaign. But there are not enough maps and only two varieties: Free Play and Challenge. Multi-player cooperative horde mode (up to four players on a team), fighting waves of enemies, in either Survive (what it says) or Defend (repair / defend something while waves of enemies attack). There are eight multiplayer maps, each in two varieties for 16 maps in all. There is some fun to be had here, but with so few people playing the game, matchmaking is a problem. You won't be able to get 100% of the game's achievements without getting some folks to help you out. The "Path to War" DLC, now included for free, is a series of four missions that tie into the main campaign. There doesn't seem to be any reason for them to exist. Maybe the missions were rejected from the main campaign but the dev team were perhaps proud of the level design and released them anyway. The missions are fun, but it is a short, disjointed experience.I'd like to think that the dev team, knowing THQ was facing troubled times (they went bankrupt shortly after the game's release), said something like, "However big or small our budget is, that's how big /small our game will be. Whatever. Let's make it the best game that we can." And they succeeded, it's a tremendously fun game. If you enjoy playing it as much as I did, at the end you'll be wanting more. But there is no more to be had...

Posted: July 21, 2016
												VALVE HAS BROKEN THIS GAME. Apparently, an update to the steam platform has completely broken new games, so that any time the game attempts to create a new save file it crashes. This was discovered by a number of enterprising users who first noticed this with a beta version of the steam client before whatever code caused the issue was also migrated into the "stable" release everyone else gets. There are some save files out there that you can download and continue from, but really valve is basically comitting fraud by leaving the game page up, since the it's documented that a specific update to the steam client is the source of the problem. (note, the co-op infestation and single player ruin modes do still function, since they do not generate save files)Actual review:There's a bunch of stuff online about how this game isn't as good as it's predecessor, Red Faction Guerilla. From my perspective, that simply isn't true. I admittedly have a somewhat unusual point of view, since I played Armageddon first, but the improvements to the central mechanics of this series mean there's really no going back. In Guerilla, you can destroy just about anything in a variety of interesting ways based on the actual structure of whatever it is you're destroying. In Armageddon, this degree of endlessly entertaining destruction is maintained, but it's just as easy to REPAIR those items, even if they're damaged the first time you see them. Guerilla is also an open world game, whereas Armageddon is quite linear, but while I usually appreciate open world games, I guess guerilla is old enough now that it just seems...empty, outdated, and boring. It took me about 12 hours to finish the main campaign of Armageddon, and while it's a much shorter game than Guerilla, I wasn't bored at any point. It left me wanting more, which led to the relative disappointment that was Guerilla.

												My first Red Faction game was 2, followed by Guerilla - I really, really enjoyed both.There have been a lot of negative reviews for this one, but most of those compare Armageddon far too strongly (and unfairly) to Guerilla. Notice that this game is called Red Faction: Armageddon, NOT Red: Faction Guerilla 2.That being said, if you are a fan of the series, like third-person action shooters, and environment destructibility, then you will really, really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are great, with absolutely fantastic environmental destruction depending on what weapon you use. The music and sounds are good. The story is decent, plot and gameplay progression is considerably more linear than Guerilla's open-world freedom, however, you should not be coming in to this game expecting it to be Guerilla 2. The controls are easy to familiarize yourself with and the learning curve is minimal to moderate. There is a horde mode that can be played local co-op or online multiplayer (or even solo) that is extremely fun. You unlock the levels you beat and can start at whatever wave you have unlocked. Solo playthrough is fairly challenging but doable if you keep practicing.There is also a destruction mode that is insanely fun. You can choose whichever weapon loadout to use (you can swap weapons by going back to the equipment console) and just destroy everything in the environment. The magnet gun is amazing - shoot two (applicable) areas and the lighter object will fly toward the heavier one. Most of the weapons available will easily cut through most buildings and materials. You can play without a time limit or try the challenges - clearing the level within a time limit.If you like third-person shooters with a lot of action and colossal amounts of destruction, give this game a try.Highly recommend!

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Red Faction: Armageddon was quite a surprise.I got it way back in the THQ Humble Bundle on December 6th of last year, and up until now went unplayed. What a fool I was not to have tried it until now! It's a great game, and to have gotten it in a bundle? *mindblown*Armageddon is a Third-Person Shooter that puts you in the shoes of Ex-Red Faction member Darius Mason on the surface of Mars. After a series of events spanning a few years, you are set on the path to stop a madman from destroying the planet. Along you way you will face thousands of alien lifeforms hellbent on your demise.But do not worry! You have plenty of weapons with which to arm yourself. The most notable of which is the Nano Forge, a glove-like apparatus that can not only project a burst of force ahead of you, knocking back anything in its way, but can also repair ANYTHING in your environment. Found an Upgrade Station or Weapons Locker, but accidently blew it up in a battle against aliens? Come to a broken bridge that halts your advance? NO PROBLEM! Just use the Nano Forge's Repair ability to fix everything right up in seconds! You will definitely make use of this tool because literally about 98% of what you see on screen (terrain, buildings, etc) can be blown to bits. Other nifty weapons include the trusty Shotgun, 2 different sets of twin pistols (standard Pistols and later the significantly more powerful pair of Banshees <3 ), and even a Singularity Cannon, which fires a mini black hole which sucks in all around it, then explodes! One of the mose useful tools, but one that some might consider the game's way of "holding your hand", is the GPS. Simply hit tab and for a few seconds a path will be lit up showing you the way to proceed. For people who like to figure things out on their own, this may seem an annoyance or a turn-off, but for others who prefer the action, shooting, and storytelling, this won't be a problem at all.As you play you will collect Salvage, which you can use to buy upgrades, which range from more health, faster reload times, extra Nano Forge abilities, or increased damage and effectiveness with certain weapons. There was even an upgrade that awards you Salvage when defeating enemies. The game will reward you salvage for exploring your surroundings, as you will find some in dark corners of each area. Just look down every path and around every corner!All-in-all, Red Faction: Armageddon is an exciting shooter, which you will enjoy til the very end. The only downside is that I was able to complete the campaign in just under 8 hours, so it's a tad on the short side. But there are multiple game modes (like New Game Plus) and even a multiplayer I believe, to take the game further. I cannot comment on these because I just played the main campaign though.Highly Recommended

Posted: January 5, 2015
This is the first positive review I've done in a while, Jesus.Well then. This is it.I honestly didn't know what to expect. Red Faction: Guerilla was pretty fun, but the story was very... simple. Boring almost. The Multiplayer was a lot of fun, due to drunk friends, playing hide&seek and destruction. After more than a year, I decided to buy Armageddon for 2.49 on the encore sale.Basically, what Volition with Red Faction: Armageddon did, was:Everything that was missing, is now here!And now, let me elaborate. (This is where the review starts, get hyped)General World Design: This is probably one of the biggest pros. The worlddesign is non-repetitive, detailed and story-fitting. Yes, that's noticable. The fact that you can destroy everything you see makes everything even better. "Use the world to kill your enemies". Remember Battlefield 4s "Levelation"? This game does it better. A lot better. Not scripted.Story: Well, a zombie alien apocalypse outbreak mysterious ancient♥♥♥♥♥♥on Mars. That's it, and I am not going to spoil you about the story. I will try not to. That might sound boring and mainstream (especially on the zombie alien apocalypse outbreak part), but it's actually kind of addicting. I couldn't stop playing to be honest.Weapons and Equipment: We got Mars stuff. We got normal stuff. Lazer pistols. Rocket launchers. We also have nano-robot-grenade launchers and tissue destroying grenade launchers. And shotguns. Can't go wrong with a shotgun.Let's be serious, the weapons and the equipment are plain awesome. Come on, we got magnet guns right here. Magnet guns. We finally have a repair tool aswell, to repair all the things you break. In single player and multiplayer. That's a necessity by the way, you'll use it a lot.Gamemodes: Well, we got Single Player, Co-Op Survival and Co-Op Protection. But let me give you a heads up: You WILL just run around destroying every building and playing around with the environment. Co-Op is insane fun. Like, INSANE fun.  Destruction. Magnet guns. Many zombie aliens. And to top the gamemodes off, we have FREE DESTRUCTION MODE in SINGLE PLAYER. Yes. Destruction without a timelimit. That was the biggest contra in Red Faction: Guerilla, because it didn't exist. BUT IT DOES NOW.Level system: Exists for both Multi- and Single Player. And guess what, the skills you have earned and bought in Singleplayer (It's all in-game-currency [you get that mostly from destroying things {this game has no micro-transactions. No windows live. It's all good.}]) work in Multiplayer aswell. Same the other way around. So, if you are stuck in Singleplayer because you happen to play on Hard or Insane, and you want that one ability that would save you from everything but you cant afford it, do some survival with your best buddy and you'll have it in no time. And the abilities in this game are awesome. It's like having the force. For example, a plasma wave that destroys everything in your path, or a shockwave that stuns your enemies, lifts them up in arcs of electricity, kills them slowly or allows you to smack the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them. Every enemy is liftable. No enemy is too heavy for the magnet gun either. Last but not least (actually very much least after all that awesome sh!t)...Graphics: Textures look horribly upscaled on 4K. Alright on 1440p. Perfect on 1080p. Framerate amazing. Everything good on the performance part. Anti-Aliasing exists. Let's be honest, what did you expect me to say about the games graphics? Just can check that out yourself. You have the internet.Red Faction was always known for having the best destruction. And here they go again. Still here with the best destruction.In the end, this game should be a solid 9/10 for anyone who likes what they see here.Anyway, I hope this helped. :)

Posted: October 27, 2014
												Download size: about 8 gigabytes if I remember correctlyPlay time: about 8 hours (with the DLC)Red Faction Armageddon (RFA) is the latest in a series of games made famous for their “destroy the environment” gameplay. Like its predecessors, in RFA you can use your sledgehammer or guns to blow apart basically anything that is “manmade” in the game. This includes walls, bridges, and entire buildings. You can’t break through “natural” obstacles like cave walls, the floor, or most rocks on the ground. A lot of people I’ve spoken to seem to think that RFA is a step down from the previous game Red Faction Guerilla, but I like RFA more. For one thing, it’s much more straightforward and action based (Guerilla was an open world sandbox game like Grand Theft Auto on Mars).You don’t need to have played the previous games to get into Red Faction Armageddon since this game takes place a generation or two after Guerilla. Now the “Red Faction” is the legitimate military of Mars and you’re one of them (in the previous games they were rebels). In RFA you play Darius Mason, an engineer with an artificial intelligence computer companion named Sam who helps you out, like Cortana in the Halo series. Your enemy is Hale, some kind of cult leader who tricks you into unleashing an ancient alien race sealed deep underground. The rest of the game is spent trying to fix your mistake.RFA is a third person “over the shoulder” shooter game with a variety of weapons and “super powers.” The super powers are part of the Nano Forge technology that Darius wears on his wrist and can get you out of any jam. You have Impact (a force push), Shockwave (lifts up enemies around you), Berserk (some kind of damage buff), and Shell (an area effect shield).  All of the powers share the same cooldown bar. Money in the game is “salvage” just like Red Faction Guerilla. Salvage is glowing junk that is left over when you blow stuff up and can also be found just lying around. You mostly spend the salvage upgrading your character, but you can also unlock cheats like infinite ammo or vehicle weapons (guns that are usually mounted on vehicles but you can now use when walking around). Speaking of vehicles, there are a bunch of times when you get into an EXO suit or an assault walker and run around blowing stuff up with your heavy weapons. In the Path to War DLC for the game, you spend most of the time in vehicles. The DLC adds about 2 hours more gameplay and a few easy achievements. I haven’t tried the multiplayer much since the game has been out long enough that nobody’s playing online anymore. You can use the “Infestation” game mode to grind for more salvage since Infestation shares the same unlocks as the single player campaign. Any upgrades you buy in Infestation (except cheats) can be used during the campaign and vice versa.  Infestation is a survivor mode where you just kill waves of aliens, which get more powerful as you progress. It can get boring fast though, since you don’t really get penalized for dying (and there’s nobody to play with). Pros:+Excellent graphics and story. The aliens are freaky looking and it’s always fun blowing stuff up. The game mostly takes place underground, but there are a lot of buildings that you can bring crashing down. The Nano Forge can also repair broken things, so if you accidently destroy a ladder or stairs, you can rebuild it in seconds.+In one playthrough of the game you can unlock most of the skills, and there is a new game+ option where you can start over, keeping everything you bought. During the second playthrough you’ll get enough salvage to unlock all the upgrades you missed, plus a couple of cheats, which can be used for higher difficulty levels. The cheats do NOT disable Steam achievements.Cons:-Multiplayer is dead. You won’t find anyone to play with online unless you set it up beforehand.-Like most over the shoulder games, you might get a headache the first few times you play. It varies by person though, and you’ll get used to the perspective eventually.Overall, the game is great and you should give it a try if you haven’t already. A lot of people probably got this game from the THQ bundles back when THQ was going out of business. The main game takes maybe 7 hours to beat, so you can finish it in a weekend and rake in a few Steam achievements while you’re at it. You get about half the achievements just playing through the game one time.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												First impression.This is what happens when you take something that is good and try to make it mainstream. Red Faction Guerilla was one of my favorite open world sandbox "GTA style" game, and that's saying alot, since there's only a handful of those games I find most of them boring and repetitive. Admittedly, even I was eventually bored by the RFG singleplayer over time simply because that genre does that to me. What Armageddon does is basically take all the good parts of RFG, but turn it into a bog standard, linear corridor third person shooter. Remeber destroying damn near every object to gather salvage? Don't bother with that here, as salvage is only found via pickups and exploding barrels, essentially discouraging environmental destruction because you need it for cover (and using the repair mechanic, while pretty nifty, seems a tad inefficient when it's destroyed as soon as you rebuild it) and encouraging the typical "blow up the red barrels" trope that has existed since Doom. Some how, Red Faction: Armageddo makes environmental destruction boring. How can that be possible? The sound assets feel lifeless - you don't hear buildings creaking as much when you destroyed most of its support, guns don't have any "oomph" to their sound feedback, destruction, especially with weapons that disintegrate objects is so quick that they feel more like magical or technical teleportation spells than actual explosions and deconstruction. Despite the quality of the game assets, the game just has no character, even down to the typical  "soldier needs to save the day plot". I messed around with the Free Mode, which gave me access to what I assume is end game weaponry, and even those weapons, such as the Plasma Beam, Rocket Launcher, and SINGULARITY CANNON had barely mild entertainment value at best - the gunplay is absolutely boring and is puzzling, as it was so good in RFG that I loved playing the multiplayer for the gunplay (I actually used the guns more than the Sledgehammer or backpacks, which brings me to another point that there aren't any backpacks!). Even the assault rifle feels weak, damn near useless, and not competent with head shots (my bullets always miss the dot on the crosshair, and it still takes like 5 headshots to kill a standard grunt)There's a multiplayer horde mode that looks ok, but practically nobody is playing this game any more and there's plenty of co-op shooters to play on PC. Thankfully, I got this through a bundle so I think I only technically paid less than $1 for this. I can't honestly recommend this, unless you played all the other good 3rd person shooters to death and just want something else to play, or you like run-of-the mill modern, third person shooters and would like to play one with a slightly interesting destruction/repait mechanic. Everybody else should not bother.

												Red Faction Armageddon is a third person rail shooter, and even if i'm not a fan nor a vet of the gerne i really enjoyed it.The narrative is actually good enough, surely the plot is not amazing in itsef, but thanks to a good mix of badass, funny (thanks S.A.M.) and dramatic (in particular THAT dramatic moment) well written lines and moments it really becomes a very pleasant experience, (the absence of secondary quests or other errands which could break the "flow" of the main story may also be a plus in this regard). Most levels also have a very good atmospheric feeling.The gameplay is very solid, you have bunch of very different weapons at your disposal (the magnet gun, you never grow tired of that:), plus the distruction mechanics (i think is the best i've seen in a game so far) really let you solve the various challenges you have to face with different approaches, also boosting replay value. Also a nice character progression is implemeted and you may upgrade Darius' gear and abilities proceding in the game.On the technical side graphics are very good, in particular the explosion looks gorgeous, and the performance were fine. I've not expereinced any glitch, bug or crash (but other rewiers instead did).Once you finish the story you have a story+ option that let you replay it with all your upgrades and special weapons (ever dreamed of disintegrating your enemy with a rainbow ray coming out from a pony's♥♥♥♥♥ I didnt but whatever) unlocked from the start.There are also a singleplayer destruction mode that can be a lot of fun and a very good multiplayer coop survival mode (even if recently might be hard to find players online).Conclusion: I really enjoyed this game (completed the main story 2 times and i'll probably come back for more sooner or later) and i surely raccomend it to anyone which is interested in pleasant, linear, story-driven shooter experience.Useless comparison with Guerrilla (if you are not interested in sterile debates or stupid comparison skip this section)Comparing Armageddon and Guerrilla really dont makes much sense, one is a story driven linear shooter while the second is an open world TPS (you have to free a bunch of outpost, assault a bunch of convoys etc.. when you are done move to the next sector and start again)... i played both and i would surely choose Armageddon over guerrilla... but that really depends on your personal tastes.

												Red Faction ArmageddonRating 7/10Overview: Linear Third Person ShooterThe Good:+ Varied locations, despite taking place on Mars every location feels unique and varied. + Good sense of pacing, the game introduces new vehicles, enemies, weapons throughout the journey to keep things fresh+ Variety of different weapons that are very unique and fun to use that fit different play styles. + Like previous Red Faction Games, this game features impressive building destruction.   + Solid controls  + Destroying buildings, killing enemies allows you to gain salvage which is used to upgrade your character, weapons and abilities + Infestation Mode (Horde Mode) allows you to fight wave after wave of enemies. The Average:Ruin Mode allows you to destroy environments within a time limit to score as many points as you can. It is a great idea that seems very underutilized given it only has a handful of maps. The previous Red Faction game had the same mode but it was much more fleshed out in its execution so this was a bit of a disappointment. The game has a lot of enemy variation but it certainly doesn't feel that way. For most of the game you will be fighting the same 3 types of enemies over and over again. Main campaign will take around 6 hours to completeThe DLC is decent but also very short. The levels are not as well designed as the main campaign.  The Bad:- The story is decent if a bit simple in its premise, it doesn't feel as developed as it should and serves more as an excuse to kill hordes of enemies. Given the location and history of Red Faction it seems like wasted potential. - Multiplayer achievements which are now almost impossible to obtain. ConclusionI can't recall another series that has had more changes each entry than Red Faction. The first game was a linear first person shooter similar to half life. The second was a level based first person shooter with bosses. The third was an open world third person shooter. This game is a linear level based third person shooter with upgrades. At this rate its only a matter of time before we see Red Faction the real time strategy game. This is a good game but plays it entirely safe with its gameplay and design. The potential is here for something special but never achieves it.

												Red Faction: Armageddon is an action packed third person shooter which follows up from the previous Red Faction: Guerrilla game and continues the Red Faction story line. However, this time the game sticks with the third person view from Guerrilla and also drops the open world concept and is linear like the first original two games. The storyline and missions are still fun as ever and works out well even though the amazing open world from Guerrilla is gone. The gameplay is pretty standard, but lots of fun and you also have a new nifty magnet gun and some powers with the Nano Forge which sometimes make you feel like a superhero or a Jedi. Once again the highlight of the Red Faction series is blowing stuff up, and you can blow up all the structures and also repair things since enemies will often be attacking you and stairs and other things you need to access will be gone. Lastly, there's an Infestion (Horde) mode which is tons of fun where you have to stay alive and fend off all of the enemies. Overall, this game is a lot of fun and is not like the previous game, however for what it is - you'll have a blast playing by blowing things up and fighting off evil cultist and aliens. I spent around 12 hours beating the story and also the DLC campaign (super short) and playing around in Infestion mode.Note: If your game crashes during checkpoints in DX10/11 Mode, turn Shadows OFF. This worked for me and the game never crashed again since I did this.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Linear as is most liearly-possible. I'll try not to compare, as Armageddon is a game in its own right of course, but it is, however, part of the Red Faction franchise... so I'm going to compare anyway. To start: why? I'm utterly amazed by design decisions that went into this game. RF Guerrilla is an open world, near sand box-destruction, action-shooter. Completing RF Guerrilla, I thought "Wow. Great game. The next'll be even better! It'll be in a dense, grimy, overpopulated martian city! Yeah! I'm going to be able to bring entire sky-scrapers to the ground!". Nope.GEOMOD 2.0Of course, the destruction engine is fantastic. Any better than Guerrilla? Collapsing structures have an effect on camera, and deal varying degrees of damage to enemies and you, according to their size/weight. This aspect I feel has improved from RFG as there feels like a real weight hangs behind each structure and destroying one is both a satisfying and almost awesome experience. Why almost? Well, I've seen it. Done it in RFG; this game makes no attempt to scale up from its predecessor, and if you havn't played RFG, then destroying small structures that are verticaly impared, (Of course they're going to be; The game's set underground), will get pretty old, very quickly. That's another thing; the game's setting just doesn't allow for the exploitation of this franchise's destruction engine! I mean, what good is blowing up stuff if you can't see more than 3 meters ahead of you!! The game doesn't even allow you to manually activate your flashlight! Overall, this destruction engine is just wasted, and it's easily the best feature of the game.NARRATIVEBah I havn't even completed it. Honestly, I got bored. That might speak volumes to you, about the game, or about me in fact, eitherway, I washed my hands of the story instantly. It's good in short bursts; I've been on and off the game, but I'm in no way hooked. It's the destruction engine that keeps me playing the game.GAMEPLAYYour standard 3rd-person perspective; the camera is of good distance from the character and worked well without any issues.Good god- Agile bullet-bags! All of them! Small arms weapons, such as your pistols, assault rifle, shotgun, are all just a bit...meh. There's no stopping power behind them, and that's hugely unsattisfying. Enemies dart around, in and out of sight, usualy never bieng able to hit you or, for that matter, doing any real damage. They feel merely time consuming and tedious, for the most part, thanks to frantic AI and pea-shooters for weapons. This isn't the case for all weapons however..."AND ON THE EIGHTH DAY, GOD CREATED THE MAGNET GUN". Truly, there has never been a more fantastic, utterly enjoyable, gun in gaming history. Got a big fella getting all up in your grill? That's ok; Bring down the very building that he stands in, on top of him! Attatching a...err...clamping node first to whatever you desire, you may then fire off an attractive node somewhere adjacent to the clamping node; the clamping node, and the wall/enemy/debris to which it was attached, will be violently accelerated accross the map towards the attractive node. Chaos, death, destruction, follows. Wonderful! As I've said before, the game features primarily underground sections-this makes the game a bit dull, in terms of locations and scenery, and does not aid the linear gameplay at all, as I found myself quickly bored by the overall atmosphere of the game. The game has Exo suits that you can hop into. They're barely worth a mention; yes you're unstoppable, and a badass, but that gets boring when you're an unkillable, unstoppable, badass. Bieng unkillable, actually, I consider, is the opposite of bieng badass; What's the point of it all?! I played on normal, the reccomended setting, and this game has yet to challenge me. Enemies just feel like a tedious filler, much like all the scenic walks through the game's martian underground.Have I mentioned that the game is increadibly linear? Oh. Yes. Ah.Perhaps they were going for a more...atmospheric and cholsterphobic Red Faction game...If that is the case, they do not focus on the darker elements of the game enough; the main protagonist wipes out any trace of grit about the plot immidiately, enemies are not to be taken seriously- they are mere insects to you, only to be crushed completely and utterly with ease. With this game's setting, it could have been a horror; the enemies look terryfying enough and there's plenty of corpses strewn about. The lighting is dark and moody, and yet, these features were never focused upon; the game does nothing in the way of building any tension. Yes, this isn't the Red Faction I wanted, but this concept... It's not done well, in many of the aspects the game claims to be about. To round up, (Well done for reading this far), I'd like to say that this game is a setback for the Red Faction franchise; the design decisions that are present baffle me, in comparison to Red Faction: Guerrilla, and in some cases just downright backwards. The game's predecessor aside, Armageddon itself is just boring, samey, and needlessly restricted in many aspects. The engine's destruction is good, fantastic, in fact, but that's all I've really got out of this game. Without Geomod 2.0, the following rating would have been far worse.5/10. Worth a 90% off, for the somewhat restricted spectical of the Geomod 2.0 engine, but otherwise, buy Red Faction: Guerrilla.

tl;drThis is a good game and worth the money you pay for it (even more so during a sale). However, the only thing it has in common with Guerrilla is the physics and shooting mechanics, so don't expect it to be Guerrilla++ and don't buy it if you don't like linear shooters that you can complete in a day.ReviewI have heared many bad things about this game, and I therefore never bothered to even look at it. That is until I got this during a sale where I bought all red faction games as a package. I thought I may as well give it a try, and I was not disappointed. I have to say it's a really good game however it is nothing like Guerrilla, so don't judge it by the same standard.This game is a shooter with the physics mechanics of Guerrilla. The story and progression of the game is linear. I find it quite welcome, but I know others don't. That's OK, but I don't feel the bad critique it has recieved is jusified.I like the small improvements and details they have added to the game, e.g.: repairing structures, the new weapons, the improved upgrade mechanics, and the fact that you can pause cutscenes. The controls also feel very solid and it's a good shooter.All in all I think this is a good game and was totally worth the money I paid for it.

												Awful.  Just awful.  Primary reason for it's awfulness is stability.  This game will crash almost every time you hit a checkpoint, so you have to complete the entire section leading up to the crash over again each time you reboot from the crash.  This happens regardless of what alleged "fixes" you apply.Aside from that, the game is a corridor shooter in which the camera is glued to your right shoulder. Endless waves of enemies.  Less and less frequent upgrade stations the more you play.  Said stations only allow you to upgrade to certain tiers after reaching arbitrary points of the story.  Speaking of the story.  It's another component of the awfulness.  The events are predictable and cliched.  The dialog is sarcastic and annoying.  The characters are 100% forgettable and consist primarily of your sarcastic♥♥♥♥♥ your "straight man" AI companion, and a token black guy.I'd say the only saving grace is the combat, but considering it's just average, only slightly better than Guerrilla, and surrounded by the crap that the rest of the game is comprised of, it's not a saving grace.  Just a minor distraction from the rest of this exercise in patients.Oh, and the climactic battle of the game is a ♥♥♥♥ing  stationary escort mission that lasts 20 minutes on normal difficulty

												The game is above average, it has solid action, controls and sound design. It also retains the long running Red Faction theme of being able to destroy just about everything, but this time you are also given tools that can fix any damage done as well, which was sadly underutilized.Characters are nothing special or memorable, the story itself has a good sense of humanity on Mars being overrun by monsters, but pacing itself feels uneven; othertimes it feels like taking too much time in one place and others seems to progress at breakneck speed.The conclusion is also solid and doesn't really leave any unanswered questions, just an open ending of what happens next.However, the biggest reason this game is not as good as it should be is simple; Red Faction Guerrilla.Where RFG was an open world action adventure game that brought the game leaps of new ideas and gameplay to work with, Armageddon takes steps back and turns it into a linear 3rd person shooter.If this gameplay mechanic had been done after Red Faction 2, it would have had more success but for whatever reason they chose to alienate many fans of RFG by going back to generic action formula.This does not make Armageddon a bad game, far from it; the game is very enjoyable when you just want to have a fun shoot'em up with fully destroyable terrain with a pop corn movie feel.It just cannot escape the shadow of its predecessor nor bring us the same level of enjoyment.I recommend this if you can get it at a discount.

												Great game. Story is interesting, somewhat linear, but ties into the lore and key plot points from the other Red Faction games. The voice acting is good, visuals are fantastic and the gameplay is really, really fun. Plenty of vehicles and walkers to use and the gunplay is the best of the series. Fans of Red Faction Guerilla will enjoy the continued emphasis on destruction and will appreciate the new weapons (and the return of some old favourites). Whilst some may be disappointed by the decision to go back to a linear campaign rather than an open world, from my point of view it was a compromise they made into order to change the environment and make the gameplay work in regard to fighting the alien race known as the 'plague'. I don't think fighting in tunnels and caverns under the surface of Mars lends itself to an open-world campaign. Red Faction Guerilla was a fantastic game, and had open world elements, but it was in no way 'open world' in the way we see it nowadays in games such as GTA V, Fallout and Skyrim. You could traverse the entire map and mess around, but the missions were all in set locations, were very similar and the objectives did not vary greatly. Anyway, I love every game in the Red Faction franchise, Armageddon is no exception. Thoroughly recommend purchasing it as the campaign is a blast to play through - one of the best singleplayer experiences I have had to date. I have a lot more hours than what is shown, but played the game whilst Steam was offline so they weren't recorded :(

												To this date, this is the last game in the Red Faction franchise. It has performed rather poorly in sales and it's easy to see why.There is no more revolution or fight against oppression (which would mean human opponents), in it's stead - bug-like aliens take place. It reminds me of Alien Swarm or Alien Breed but with a much higher level of quality and that AAA feel to it. In fact it's much better then any of the new blockbusters.A special place holds the music in my mind, it's not only a new style for the franchise, but a very well made artistic move that revolves around a more claustraphobic environement - like the first Red Faction and second Red Faction games to a degree.It feels as if the identity on first glance changed, leaving nothing but the destruction aspect as a standing-out feature. In the end THQ went bankrupt and Nordic games took it's place releasing a little bit of content for free. Thank you Nordic Games!The style is much too different. But don't be fooled by that, it's still a worth conclusion to a story that went on for 10 years with an amazing aesthetic value.

The player must reclaim cultist fortifications on the disaster-ravaged surface of the planet and defend colonists from hostile Martian creatures in the ancient mines and chasms beneath it and cleansing infestations from all structures.Using the Magnet Gun, Darius, the main protagonist, fires first at one object, then at a second object, and then the first object rockets toward the second.The Nano-Forge returns, having been passed down through two generations of the Mason family. Darius' father has incorporated the tool with a function that reverses any and all destruction dealt to man-made objects. The Nano-Forge will also feature an ability known as Impact, which discharges an incredibly powerful burst of force which can blow away structures and throw enemies off their feet.Darius' Nano-Forge, weapons and armor are all upgradeable, improving their efficiency, unlocking new abilities, and altering their appearances.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game feels like it was made by talented developers following a checklist, with no regard to how the game will be received and whether the end result will be any fun. They were told to make another entry in the Red Faction franchise, so they did, got paid and moved on. I'll skip ahead and say that this game really should not exist, and it's not fun after 3-4 hours in.The game's campaign is roughly 10 hours long, even on the highest difficulty. Most of the game is spent fighting the same 3-4 enemy types in same-looking caves. The protagonist has a ton of health and regenerates quickly, the enemies are mostly armed with peashooters, and fighting them is about as difficult as playing a cow clicker game. Most of the environment is so generic and forgettable, I couldn't recall most of the game even immediately after I finished it.The destruction engine the Red Faction series is known for is there, but roughly two thirds of the environment are indestructible. Regardless, wrecking the destructible parts of the environment while enemies are in/on top of it is virtually the only fun aspect in the game.Literally every level in the game is at least twice as long as it should be, dragging on so much that I had to take breaks to do something else in order to stay awake. You would think that destroying the environment inside a walker mech armed with infinite missiles never gets old, but it does - every single vehicle scene repeats at least twice, involves no challenge and no risk of dying, and consists of mashing mouse1 for 10 or more minutes.While you can technically have fun in the game if you play it in short bursts and don't treat it seriously, the final 3 levels are disgustingly bad and *will* make you hate it. It feels like THQ told Volition the game should be at least 10 hours long, and they struggled to add enough filler to hit the 10 hour mark.There is a reason this game sold so poorly that THQ decided to terminate the Red Facton franchise. Good riddance.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Warning, this review may contain spoilers. I wasn't paying close enough attention to the story to tell you if any of the events were foreshadowed or not. Read at your own risk, since I'm not recommending the game, I don't think you're missing much by seeing some of the minor plot points.It's hard to write an in depth review about this game because it does so little that is new or unique. This is essentially a by the numbers over the shoulder shooter and will fail to keep the attention of those who don't find the "story" interesting or capturing, but few are going to be really captivated by it.The games gimmick is that you can destroy areas of the world and rebuild them again using some magical nano builder gizmo that apparently only you possess. I wasn't paying close enough attention to the story to figure out if they ever explained why you're the only one with one of these tools. While it sounds interesting on the surface, the destruction tends to feel unsatisfying after the first few times. Most of the time when you are actually noticing the destruction physics going on around you, it is because an enemy with an explosive ability has destroyed the area you were standing on and then you get to rebuild it later once you've defeated them.Enemy variety is fairly limited, and the environments while pretty, are fairly boring to look at and consist mostly of being in tight corridors or in an enclosed outdoor space. Very rarely is there ever any wide open areas. You get your basic trash enemies that you spam the melee key to get rid of, the typical flies around and is annoying but not really dangerous enemies, and then the takes a bunch of ammo to kill enemies that have more powerful attacks. It doesn't get any more complex than that. Some of the enemy designs blend in quite nicely with the environment, and while they tried to add special effects to make them stand out, they were sometimes unsuccessful to make them visually distinct from what they are attached to.Mason has to be one of the dumbest and unluckiest protagonists I've seen in a video game. He's repeatedly tricked, knocked out, and captured, and he repeatedly runs into situations without a plan, without backup, and without thinking things through, often cutting off the recommendations of his personal assistant computer which is trying to give him good advice. It's hard to feel sorry for him and hard to feel connected with him or his plight, which seems to be mostly self inflicted. If anyone on the entire planet of Mars had a few brain cells they could have probably resolved the entire story of the game within 3 days of the introduction.The primary mission objectives are to destroy something, fix something, run around in mazes killing enemies, kill all the enemies, and escort vehicles through heavily scripted events. Most of it is in the guise of him being a good guy and helping out, but a lot of it just feels tedious and forced, just padding out gameplay length. The whole game can be rushed through in about 6 hours if you feel like it, and it isn't terribly hard even on some of the higher difficulty levels. Difficulty curve is fairly flat other than an occasional spike and a hard upwards curve at the end of the game where they throw everything they have at you.Most of the weapons feel unrewarding to use and enemies act like bullet sponges until you begin upgrading. The weapon variety is decent, offering you some fun toys to play with, but you'll likely pick the weapons you like in the first half of the game and never venture out into the newer heavy weapons that the game gives you. Ammo for the heavy weapons tends to feel as though they are giving you very little of it, or way too much of it, depending on the situation. You'll need to keep some of the standbys with you anyways because while the game lets you choose any four weapons, you don't want four heavy weapons. The fire rate is too low and the ammo too limited.There are some fun mech segments in the game, and the unlimited ammo gets put to good use, but it makes you part with the suits too quickly for that high powered, bullets actually kill things feeling to last. Generally you're walking around at a modest pace, and going from place to place takes time, often more than I'd have liked, giving the game a plodding feeling to it. There is a sprint mechanic, but it doesn't last very long and has a moderate recharge time before it can be used again, leading me to believe it is more for panic events than travel. The dodge mechanic feels slightly clunky as it is tied to the jump key, and while useful in some situations, I didn't find myself using it very much.You are given a GPS which always shows you where you need to go, and the pathfinding for it is top notch, working around broken obstacles, or pointing out the path even in there is something broken that is required to advance. You'll make good use of it should you choose to play the game.If you're looking for an over the shoulder shooter that lets you shoot things, has some pretty physics and decent graphics and audio, but not much else, this is right up your alley. If you're looking for something that a plot you can, and want to follow, and something that isn't going to get boring after a few hours, then you should look elsewhere. If this game suffers from anything, it's being too average and mundane.

												This is an odd game to recommend on Steam mostly because it doesn't have a neutral option. For fans of the Red Faction series, do not buy this game. It will shatter any love you have for the franchise because of its interactive environments, diverse enemies, and deep storyline, because this game has none of those. If you don't understand what I just said, Red Faction is dead, and Armageddon killed it.On the other hand, if you take the game for what it is, and ignore the Red Faction stamp at the beginning of the game, stand alone this is a good game. Not game of the year material, or "OMG do you remember that game we played 5 years ago?", but still a fun experience. Best part about it by far is the magnet gun, you can have hours of fun tethering two enemies together to their death. The story is decent, graphics are good, and you even get a few mech moments. All in all, if you can get past the idea that this should have been a good addition to the Red Faction franchise, you would like this game.

Posted: October 19, 2013
												Any game that gives you a maul for beating things up is a good game in my book. This is a standard action-shooter, closed world, with nothing too special in its pallette, but adds in the fascinating realm of a mostly destructable environment. content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Red Faction: Armageddon gets flak for being short and not living up to the acclaim of the previous title in the franchise, Guerilla. But it's still a good game.You play as Darius Mason, the grandson of Alec Mason from Guerilla. Set fifty years after Guerilla, the premise is that the Cultists and their leader, Adam Hale take control of the terraformer, the machine which supplies Mars with its sustainable atmosphere. Darius, working with Red Faction forces, try to assault the terraformer and take back control. Ultimately, the Cultists end up destroying the terraformer and some time later, Darius is a contractor taking on drilling jobs in the underground. Things go awry when, on a certain drilling job he takes on, he awakens an infestation. Turns out he was set up and now he has to save the planet and bring order back to civilization. Along with some help.The unique mechanic in this game is the nano energy and SAM. SAM is like Cortana, but not as emotional. She helps you decrypt things, unlock doors, give you power ups, etc. The nano energy is cool, like the repair mechanism so that you can rebuild bridges you need to cross over canyons or lava flows.The enemies include both the Cultists and the infestation of bugs. The bugs were a dormant species living on Mars that Adam Hale had tricked Mason into waking. They're kind of what you'd expect, and more. They vary in size from flying little things that annoy you, to walking fiends that fire lasers at you. And giant behemoths that charge and shoot green gases at you. And tentacles that pummel you. Basically, there are plenty of enemies and you'll never be bored fighting them.Most of the game takes place in the underground, and I think the devs really nailed Mars' undreground. Mars seems like the place where the underground would be vast and large with flowing lava in various places. But also gloomy and dreadful because life on Mars means being in constant fear of death from seperate factions or unknown species. Especially underground where there are unexplored territories and systems that may have been abandoned long ago. It's really interesting to think about, honestly. You don't see much topside beside the opening mission and maybe two or three more bits, but over 90% of the game is underground.Everything else is nice too, graphics, sound design/mixing. Rarely any bugs. Music is a bit overkill with the guitars. I would have liked something more electronic to fit the mood of sci-fi action. Or at least more orchestral. But the guitars and drums didn't do it for me.Anyway. The game's plot started iffy for me, but I grew into it and ended up really liking it. Also, start a new game plus after you beat it for the possibly the greatest weapon out there, Mr. Toots: a mini-unicorn you carry that shoots rainbow plasma from its booty.8.5/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												In short, this game is no RF: Guerrilla. However, this game is still great fun and I thoroughly enjoyed playing through it. I bought the game on sale for $7.50 so perhaps that's why I'm not as critical when it comes to reviewing it. As someone who has little time and a lot of stress, this game provided me with an outlet to destress and I loved every minute of it. Sure, the sandbox is gone, but the destruction and carnage are still there. Nothing brought me more joy than bringing down an infected building with cool and creative weapons, or blasting through enemies with badass vehicles. As an RF fan, I enjoyed the small touches they placed here and there to build upon the lore. Little things references to the RF history I thought were pretty cool and even how the Terraformer had the EDF symbols on it still were a nice touch. Is the game a setback from Guerrilla? Yes, but not a huge one. It's definitely worth a playthrough, at least during a flash sale. It's great, mindless fun and decently long. The enemies, while perhaps a cross between the Flood and Necomorphs, are entertaining to cut down and you learn a good deal about the RF world in the process.

												Red Faction: Armageddon is mostly judged because it wasn't Red Faction: Guerrilla. Guerrilla was the better game, but this is by no means worse because it's not an imitator. For what it is, it's just not very interesting.  It's pretty obvious that the fun factor in Guerrilla made it so well liked, because this isn't nearly as interesting. 												I'll give it an 8/10 (on my  scale) . The single player campaign is pretty long and satisfying. Enjoyed most of the game like around 95% .Few part had too much enemies lol but it was fun dying at different places :P . The best part that i literally enjoyed was reconstruction. Since most the structures, actually almost everything, in the game is destructible hence it can be rebuilt too :3 too much fun. I dont care of the graphics but still for the sake of review just a comment 'pretty good'. The bosses are pretty damn easy too kill(once you know where to attack), not VERY EASYYY but yes you wont die (max maybe once but not more than that). Lots of weapons but cannot carry then all well you get a lot of opportunities in the levels to change them according to your style. A hand full of upgrades but make sure you look out for nanites(the currency ingame to buy upgrades). They are spread out in almost every corner of the level even at places you dont neeed to visit. (just for sharing i - I was able to unlock around 85% of upgrades)The one weapon which has a unique twist to it is the MAGNET GUN. Most guns would shoot, launch grenades or rockets or even vapourising beams but NO this gun?! well it shoots magnets powerful enough to destroy a whole building. The uniqueness isnt in this though, the uniquness lies in the fact that you can actually throw an aliens at stuff around you. And if not that you can go entirely opposite of it, throw stuff at the alien with it (everything else you'll get to know ingame not gonna spoil it all :P )Once you finish the game you have 'NEW GAME +' too, just like most other games now-a-days. Also you have a few rewards once you complete the game which you get to use in 'NEW GAME +' mode ^_^I highly recommend this game to those who are die hard shooting fans and of destruction.ALL IN ALL I HAD A PRETTY GOOD TIME PLAYING THIS. content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												After the great open world Red Faction Guerilla, Volition take the series in another direction. Stripping the open world in favour of a tight, linear structure turned a lot of people of to this game as did the focus on fighting alien bugs rather than a human threat. If you can play beyond the first third of the game however up to when you get back to the surface of Mars  the game does open up a little into more open canyons with some great vehicular destruction.The game features the meatiest story in the series and follows directly on from the SyFy movie Red Faction origins with you playing another decendant in the Mason family responsible for allowing the Martian atmosphere processor to be destroyed by Cultists and in turn letting lose a whole nest of alien creatures from underground. The story ties back into the previous games and playing them first would be benifical.Weapons are inventive and forceful and are fun to use, especially the mechs and tanks and their respective missions.Visuals have gotten better from the last game and there is still destruction of buildings but this time you can bring anything back with the new Nano rebuilder to recreate destroyed stair ways etc so you are not stuck trying to climb the geometry to make progress after a fire fight which was a problem in guerilla.The only problem is the Aliens are used a lot and are thrown against you overwhelmingly at some points so it can get a little repetative fighting them again and again.Overall if you're coming back here for more of Guerilla you will be dissapointed but if you enjoyed the first game's structure or like linear shooters in general theres fun to be had here.7.5/10

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												An intriguing third-person-shooter take on the traditional 'Mars settlers encounter alien lifeforms' genre. The story takes obvious cues from similar settings, but what the story lacks, the game makes up with amusing and interesting gameplayStory Pros:- The main character is easy to understand and grasp his personality.- The importance of the previous games in the series is minimal; what you need to know to understand the story is all contained in dialog etc., so you won't feel lost if you haven't played the previous games.- The main character is able to communicate important details of what's going on without directly talking to the player, thanks to his dialog with his "S.A.M." AI on his wrist.- The comraderie of the main character and a number of his acquiantances makes it easy to enjoy dialog, instead of it feeling like dead-pan exhibition.Story Cons:- Due to the importance of your character's past, you cannot customize your character at all visually.- The S.A.M. AI on the character's wrist is near omnipotent at times, like finding routes for you through completely uncharted caves, yet other times seems completely oblivious to certain details.- The story will frequently, intentionally mislead you through certain portions of the story, often through the AI either not providing all the details, remaining silent, etc. This tends to create a feeling of Deus Ex Machina when the Story says you can do X thing to fix the situation, long after you should reasonably have been told, or even after it made it seem like that thing was impossible (No spoilers, but the ending definitely reeks of this)- There are a number of cuts the story takes through Cutscenes. The cutscenes themselves are actually quite nice, however, there are a number of occasions where the game will painstakingly walk you through every detail of a particular scenario, and the abruptly move you to the next chapter with no details of what happened in between (I.E. cutscene shows you loading up on a truck with your buddy, talking about where they're going, and then it immediately goes to another cutscene where you've been at that location for some time and are already talking about heading out again.)Gameplay Pros:- Physics & Destructible terrain are immensely enjoyable. This is seriously the best thing about the game. As you progress, you get a number of unique weapons and skills that will wreak havoc on your surroundings. And once you've had your fill of destroying buildings and sending your enemies flying, your AI can use a 'Nano forge' to repair things like bridges, so you need not worry about accidentally destroying your path to the next objective.- There is never any time where the game takes away your progression through the skill tree, nor any of your weapons. Once it's unlocked, you can expect it to be available for the rest of the game.Gameplay Cons:- Objectives aren't always clear as to how you should get where you are going, unless you use the 'Compass' tool which projects the direction to your goal onto the terrain around you. There's no middle ground between, "I'm lost" and Handholdiong from the game. I would have liked more well-designed levels that make it a little easier to find where you are going without asking for an explicit map.- Gameplay time is fairly short. Two full playthroughs took me just under 12 hours.Visuals:- Textures are magnificent. The developers knew what they were dealing with, and didn't leave anything blurry or pixelated.- Meshes are a little angular at times, but instead of looking odd, they made sure to make the artistic style incorporate angles as seeming intentional (i.e. crystals on the walls, angular architecture, and spiky enemies)Overall, I definitely recommend the game simply because of how enjoyable it is to be able to destroy the large majority of your surroundings. It makes you feel in control, and powerful. It's definitely not a legendary game like Half-Life 2 or Portal, but it's a good 6 or 7 out of 10. Definitely worth a shot if you see it go on sale.

												First warning: Since THQ went down the tubes, there's nobody left to support this game. So when you run into the bug that makes it impossible to start a new game, you'll have to find someone else's save-game from the start and work from there.It turns out that work just isn't worth it. Red Faction: Armageddon keeps basically nothing of what made Red Faction: Guerrilla so fun and swaps the big open world and destructible environment mayhem for a humdrum alien shooter restricted to caves. The Magnet Gun is a pretty sweet gimmick but is only as strong as the amount of debris made available to you. Guerilla may have benefited from a little curation because its setpiece fights were so good, but Armageddon over-curates your experience into a straight-line slog through endlessly replaceable alien bugs. It just doesn't belong in the same series as Guerrilla. Buy Red Faction: Guerrilla instead.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2013
												Big part of the people who are interested in this game, are going to want it because of Red Faction: Guerilla. So I'll be adjusting my recommendation with that in context.As comparisons go, the first one is as simple as this: The story is now lineair and you are no longer in a free-roaming world. With that, means that the walls surrounding your path are unbreakable. However, this doesn't mean that desctruction is very absent.On the contrary, destruction and debris play a much bigger role than they did in Guerilla. In said game, your sledgehammer served for nothing to break down buildings, maybe kill those inside.In Armageddon, debris is a potential weapon. The Magnet gun is the tool of the trade now. It's functioning is two-staged: You attach/shoot first what you want moved, then attach the second magnet to where you want it to go. This can be structure parts, pickups or even enemies (all but the biggest Behemoth).This makes for some fun and unique gameplay. And while the tool is powerful and relatively fast, you'll still be needing some firearms. Because the Alien swarm is fast and massive.Besides that, the weapons array is pretty much classic. Shotguns, Assault/Sniper rifles and two sets of dual pistols. The Sniper rifle does feature a heat-mode that allows you to see and headshot through surfaces, which is the only reason the sniper is not obsolete, as vantage points are nigh unexistant.I won't spoil the story because... it's not that extraordinary. Saying anything about it may as well spoil it all. It's classic, a little bit cheesy but not too annoying.S.A.M. however, that's a new box of toys. S.A.M. is your wrist-mounted A.I. that serves a guiding purpose in the story, and a more practical one in combat. You start out with a repair functionality. Anything destroyed can be repaired by the nano-forge that is built in.Which means, you now have a new renewable weapon in debris, as well as a renewable cover source. Too bad there's no cover mechanic. Just crouching, and that's it.The Impact skill basically serves as a short-range air bash that pushes back any debris in it's path. Of course, this makes the sledgehammer pretty obsolete. (which can now be swapped out)It also makes for a nice punching weapon, though eventually you'll want to power it up with upgrades.Besides that, you have three classical 'extra' skills you can get through the upgrade station. Berserk ups your damage and fire speed, Shockwave (that I didn't even bother to try) is a typical Nova ability, and the Shell works as a projectile shield (great for when you're almost dead) and DoT for enemies that are inside of it.As per enemies go... it's a good thing your toys are more destructive rather than precision based. AFAIK 25% of the enemies you encounter are human. And they tend to be pushovers, even at Hard difficulty.The real threat are the Alien creatures. They all come in several ranks, and tend to just swarm you late-game, with the low-rank creatures coming in masses and tending to be very melee based.But, even on Hard mode, the only real threats are the Berserkers are the Behemoths. Berserkers are quite tough and are hard hitting on both ranged and melee. But they can just be punted around with the magnet gun and melee'd to death once you've taken care of the other critters.Behemoths, when not encountered while in a vehicle, tend to be mini-boss fights. The area is locked off and you need to use your weapons or available debris to kill them. They're real bullet spunges and hit pretty hard in ranged and melee.And they can't be punted around.While in a vehicle, they are the only types of enemies that really pose a threat if not paid any attention to.Eventually though, you'll find a gimmick that works for you and they just become a nuisance. Much like the other aliens, really.This is a game with a gimmick that plays it very, very well. But sadly, it can't lean on it to justify a full price. Maybe if it had been free-roaming. But regardless, the game is not something you should avoid simply because of that.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												The story of Red Faction Armageddon can be easy to forget as it strikes as something bland without many surprises aside from a couple of plot twists moments a bit of love here or there and many, many explosions. However, while many games have a deep narrative with a strong storyline Red Faction is worth a play, especially for a nice fill if you are looking to relax and play something easy-to-follow with a love for destruction (and construction). Just like many movies, there are the ones that you can’t wait to go to the cinema and watch it while others you just stumble while zapping on your TV in a lazy Sunday. Red Faction Armageddon is the latter but by any means does this means that it was not an enjoyable experience. Despite being short my time with the game was worth my time investment. In under 6-7 hours I finished the main story and I was happy with the ending although I wish it could have lasted me a bit more.The bigger fun factor has to be all the destruction and the variety of weapons. While I got stuck in the geometry a couple of times after destroying things, nothing like make use of my hammer with the combination of the reconstruction ability to get out of a mess of concrete wall that just crumbled on my feet. From sending grenades and then hit “detonate” to sticking enemies in the walls there is a bit of everything for any gun lover. Assault Rifles and Shotguns are also present in the game but considering the satisfaction from shooting the other weapons these tend to be forgotten through most of my play through.  Besides the standard shooting the enemy with said weapons, some vehicles will be at your disposal during certain missions. These will be armored vehicles to destroy the enemy and can be driven by land or air however, the sound effects felt a bit poor when firing some missiles or other bigger weapons. The visuals are nothing out of the ordinary but considering the time the game was released (2011) my experience in 2015 was not diminished by this, it was all about destroying and exploding things from start to finish and overall I can say it was a positive experience. If you have a little time to spend on something to play in little chunks of time without having to worry about complex systems or controls I would recommend giving Red Faction Armageddon a fair chance. You can play the game in short bursts since it provides a gentle checkpoint system.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Let me start off by saying that I hated Guerilla. I gave it at least 3 separate tries and on each occasion I felt dumber and dumber playing it. The game had huge and bland lifeless environments similar to Far Cry 2 canyon-like map only with no vegetation. The Martian physics were also something that I just couldn't get used to; the game introduced the seemingly unnecessary destruction of everything even of civilian buildings; there was the un-tactical running and shooting gameplay even though there were some guerrilla type raids involved; ultimately most missions turned into run and shoot mess.I had slight hopes for this game because I was hoping that the linear single player story would at least be something to enjoy.Well, as for gameplay, this is a regular run'n'shoot BUT have-the-ability-to-destroy-everything game. There is no cover to speak of, and there's no ability to take cover and for a good reason - everything goes. That is, taking cover behind a wall will result in the wall being destroyed so you would attempt to kill the enemy before he or it kills you after blowing your cover, literally. There is no real tactical movement required - just keep on shooting and moving and you will most likely win.As you descend deeper into the Martian caves you will encounter aliens. For the most part you are going to be battling angry insectoids, small roaches, giant roaches and some other disgusting creatures including huge mean looking worms. There's some suspense to have as you go deeper and deeper into caves and the CGI cut scenes are pretty cool however, this suspense is quickly dispensed by hordes of insects swarming you from every direction throughout the game. From that point on, the game pretty much becomes a giant insect fest comprised of killing as many bugs using different weapons as well as the environment before they get you. I think I've seen this somewhere, dare I say Lost Planet 2? Only that game had co-op.Besides, for some reason, you will constantly encounter the ammo for your guns even in the deepest caves where no man has set foot. You will never run out of ammo because the ammo caches are spread out in almost every direction.The portable computer system that you have, SAM, is reminiscent of the Dead Space navigation pointer, except this time, SAM has a voice and it tells you what to do constantly. You don't really have to think or wander around caves because the SAM guiding system will tell you where to go. The game practically plays by itself.The weapons are okay. We have the usual guns as well as magnet gun that connects point A and B- this gives you the opportunity to hurl objects from point A at enemies that are located at point B. You can also destroy entire multiple story buildings and constructions with one placed shot.The graphics are great, the DX 11 and all. The water looks okay and for the most part the environments are well detailed. The aliens are sometimes revolting to look at too.You do have the ability to break through walls as well as re-construct virtually every man made structure via your molecular reconstructor or whatever, which is neat, but extremely unrealistic. So, in the end you end up with great looking engine that actually lets you destroy just about everything but at the same time lets you fix pretty much everything. Take that for what it's worth. There are also some weapon and skill upgrades you can buy with your easily earned credits.I guess the biggest disappointment is the gameplay. You just want to keep running and shooting without looking back. Or you DO look back only to shoot up some chasing insectoids while keeping on running.There are no invisible walls in the game but some battles requires you to stay within a set sector without having the ability to retreat. Thus you are given 10 seconds to get back into battle...The game is also extremely easy, even on Hard. The health regenerates within a few seconds. The game itself runs smoothly though and the controls for your character are fluid. You will be able to move fast and avoid being hit.All in all, buy the game at bargain.

												I have played all the Red Faction games that are out there and I would say that this is the least lore friendly Red Faction title to have been made it does not follow the previous title flavor and style, what all Red Faction games have is a faction of resistance members fighting a much larger Earth military and cooperate force for the freedom of the Mar colonist, most of which are miners. 												If you haven't played any of the Red faction games, you really should. There's nothing quite like them out there (although I haven't heard great things about RF2). There are so many ways to play - when you can destroy any structure in any way you want with any weapon, you suddenly have a lot of options.In Armageddon, there is a new weapon called the magnet gun that lets you pull objects together (violently) and once you figure it out, it can be a lot of fun to use. Armageddon isn't open world like guerilla was and is more linear, which was disappointing but I still liked it. I also like the multiplayer, and play local games (LAN) with a friend of mine. You can upgrade your character with "salvage" you earn - however the time you have to choose upgrades between rounds is short and often the round starts before I can choose (possibly because my friend started the round).All and all, a very worthy addition to your collection.

												This one was the first game of the series that I played, and definately it won't be the last. Most things I have to say about it are between good and great.Storyline is very good, gives you a brief awareness of what happened before the game, without spoiling the previous games, so you still feel like you must play them in order to fully understand the whole picture. Graphics are good, the destruction engine is awesome and opens a huge door for creativity. I mean, why waste ammo when you can crush a building down with your maul and let gravity kill your enemies for you? The Magnet Gun is in my personal top 3 of best video game weapons of all time. It's incredibly fun to use, and gives you an unlimited advantage over your enemy, with its unlimited ways to bring tangos down, from crushing them with one another to drag them next to you so you can be able to finish em with meele.On the other hand, I wouldn't say single player campaign is short, but it sure is a little easy, even in the insane difficulty. Sound is not extraordinary, I think it could be somewhat more intense, in order to match with the graphics and make you feel more inside of the action.In the end, I think it is a must have/play. 8/10Now let's get the rest of the series :P

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This is a typical case of developers not understanding what is good about their product. There is a way to play this game that is hugely entertaining. But there are also ways to make it incredibly boring.The right way to play this game is very simple: ignore everything that doesn't cause explosions.There's nothing satisfying about sniping jumpy aliens with a laser pistol. What is fun is blowing the alien and the building it was clinging on to shreds. Explosions are such a cliche that it is hard to explain how well it works here. We're not talking just about fancy animations and light effects. This game's destruction model makes a spectacle out of every single rocket, making holes into buildings and sending parts flying everywhere.The game tries to be more than its physics model, and it fails miserably. The story is actually so bad that it had me laughing all the way through. But you owe it to yourself to pick up a rocket launcher and blow something up. It's so good that it doesn't even get old for the 6 hours that the game lasts.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game, and it's one of those games that just stuck with me after I've finished it. The story is not bad at all, and keeps you invested from the beginning to the end. The game is very linear and there's not many options other than whats presented to you. However I don't find that a bad thing, I actually think the game benefits from it. This is not a game that you walk around exploring your enviroment or wander off on some side quest, but rather sit back and enjoy as the story unfolds itself. It's decently long and can accomplish this without making the game feel repetitiv.Now let's talk about the best part, the destruction. A lot of stuff in your environment will break, and I mean a lot. You can bash through a wall with your sledgehammer and tear down pillars and buildings to their core. This means that you can destroy any cover that the enemy might try and hide behind, but so can they. You can repair stuff to quickly make cover for yourself or you can grab a piece of a wall and swing it on your enemies. It never gets boring and will make a huge difference in how you play the game.Aside from the single-player action you can team up with some friends and play coop missions. These center around fighting waves of enemies while trying to survive. I found this to be very fun and intense gameplay, but it falls short when it comes to veriety and exensivness.If you can find this game on a sale, I would highly recommend it.

This time, an enemy thought dead came back, and unleashed hell hidden beneath Mars, and the only guy who can really do something about it... is Darius Mason... if he can survive the onslaught of multiple enemies... but he has a few friends. Will it be enough? There's a bit of auto-aim, and there are a lot of different weapons (but you can carry only 4 at a time). There's a bit of RPG element as you can choose different "skills" to enhance your combat and destructible environment such as buildings, walls, and others are pretty cool the first few times, but gets old a bit later. Still, this is an exciting shooter, if a bit repetitive.
