 Red Faction Armageddon - Review === RATING: 5.0 / 10 - Mars, Six Hundred Feet Under ===- Absolutely essential purchase- Recommended purchase- Purchase only if on sale- Purchase only if on heavy sale ->> Avoid purchasing === The Good - Environment destructiblity always gives good enjoyment in combat, in this also this Red Faction does not disappoint- Decent variety of weapons, skills and such- You can repair structures, which is a new mechanic as far as single-player campaign is concerned, in Red Faction series=== The Bad - Everything else apart weapon realization, which is decent, is MEDIOCRE at best.- There is no free-roaming: the game takes place in closed environment where you have to follow a straight path most of the time. You have freedom to destroy whatever you want, but in the end you will be on a pre-chosen path and that is what you follow. A big step back from the very good free-roaming of the previous episode, Guerrilla.- No side-quests or challenges: only one objective at a time, linear story, no chace of doing some other activity than main quest.- Storyline, which has never been a strong point in Red Faction, granted, is even more uninvolving and stereotyped than other chapters of the series, and that's something... something bad. The incipit which triggers the whole event that leads to the Armageddon is just ridiculous.=== The Ugly - Difficulty is really low if you know what you are doing: this is because the player has access to some ridiculously overpowered weapons. Most weapons you find are real crap, but one in particular, the Magnet Gun, is completely overpowered. If used correctly this weapon can just destroy any enemy in a short time, because it allows you to throw pieces of environment towards enemies to cause massive damage. It has UNLIMITED ammo and a very long range. You can also throw enemies with it, and most will be instantly killed by the impactsCombine this with some upgrades to health, armor and powers to get rid of close enemies, and there you have a really easy game. The ONLY sections with difficulty are those where you are forced to stay in tight spaces such as platforms moving and such.=== Conclusions This Red Faction is what really ruined the series in the end. Volition tried a combat-focused, alien mash up instead of doing another great red faction as Guerrilla has been, removed the key gameplay points that made the previous title great and instead of them put just a few innovations that just do not save the overall picture from being mediocre at best.This is a game i suggest only if you are a real fan of Red Faction and want to see how LOW it has gone, or also if you enjoy REALLY MUCH blasting aliens with overpowered stuff.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												This is a typical case of developers not understanding what is good about their product. There is a way to play this game that is hugely entertaining. But there are also ways to make it incredibly boring.The right way to play this game is very simple: ignore everything that doesn't cause explosions.There's nothing satisfying about sniping jumpy aliens with a laser pistol. What is fun is blowing the alien and the building it was clinging on to shreds. Explosions are such a cliche that it is hard to explain how well it works here. We're not talking just about fancy animations and light effects. This game's destruction model makes a spectacle out of every single rocket, making holes into buildings and sending parts flying everywhere.The game tries to be more than its physics model, and it fails miserably. The story is actually so bad that it had me laughing all the way through. But you owe it to yourself to pick up a rocket launcher and blow something up. It's so good that it doesn't even get old for the 6 hours that the game lasts.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												[9/10] - When I bought Armageddon, I was hoping for the same open world experience I got from Guerilla. Unfortunately, what I got was a linear story progression that didn't have the same charm as its predecessor. However, that does not at all mean it's a bad game. In fact, I enjoyed the game just as much as, if not more than, the other one.The combat in Armageddon is fluid and well played. Swinging the hammer to destroy almost every piece of the world and then bringing it back to life by repairing it in an instant allows for total control over the battlefield. There are upgrades such as shockwave which pushes your enemies away, berserk which increases damage output, and creating a defensive shell that reflects bullets. These are all unlocked through progression and can be allocated to the enhancement of your choice,  giving a noticeable and substantial edge in combat. There is also a wide choice of weapons to choose from including dual pistols, machine guns, and a rocket launcher along with its own unique array of weapons like the magnet gun and rail driver. I never felt more powerful in a game bashing enemies as a single-hero-against-all-odds than I have in Armageddon.There is also a four player co-op mode where you fight waves of enemies or complete objectives (usually defending structures) that can be enjoyable with friends. There are 15 maps total and 30 waves each, leaving plenty of variety and content to satisfy this game mode for a while.On the downside, the game is a bit short and doesn't offer too much in terms of difficulty, at least for me. Though time has passed, and price has dropped and I would HIGHLY recommend giving this game a chance. It's a fun and exciting third person shooter that has not received the love it deserves.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Review-in-ProgressBasically, this game would have done better as a new and seperate IP. It trades the oppressive military for generic alien bugs, trades wide open scenery for claustrophobic, linear cave systems, and large destructable structures for little shacks and nameless machinery that sort of fall apart with no real effort. The destruction that made Guerilla fun is now a hindrance, as the spaces are so small and linear that debris will just get in your way. Vehicles have all but been removed, which is probably a good thing in these enclosed spaces, in favor of a couple different exo-suits. These are great fun to mow down bugs in, but again, it doesnt fit a red faction game. There is some weapon variety, but there is rarely a need to switch up your loadout since there is little to no strategy required for most fights. Adding to this problem is the "nano-forge" which is a very loosely "sci-fi" way of giving your character (and only your character) abilities that basically amount to The Force. Also worth mentioning is the generic A.I voice-in-your-head, named SAM, like every generic A.I should be named, that conveniently gives you all relevant mission objectives.Visually, the game looks great, and runs smoothly even at max settings, including 4K (played using a GTX 1070). Lighting is very well done and provides a gloomy atmosphere with ominous glowing bug silhouettes dashing around and bright energy weapons flashiing across the screen. However, the majority of the time, the lighting is the only thing you'll get to appreciate, since the game is too dark to notice any other visual effects.However, If you can get this game on sale, need something to play in Steam Big Picture mode, and/or want to mow down generic alien bugs in exo-suits, this is a fairly good title. Just ignore the fact that it is supposed to be a red faction game, and dont bother listening to the "story". Just go shoot stuff.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Review-in-ProgressBasically, this game would have done better as a new and seperate IP. It trades the oppressive military for generic alien bugs, trades wide open scenery for claustrophobic, linear cave systems, and large destructable structures for little shacks and nameless machinery that sort of fall apart with no real effort. The destruction that made Guerilla fun is now a hindrance, as the spaces are so small and linear that debris will just get in your way. Vehicles have all but been removed, which is probably a good thing in these enclosed spaces, in favor of a couple different exo-suits. These are great fun to mow down bugs in, but again, it doesnt fit a red faction game. There is some weapon variety, but there is rarely a need to switch up your loadout since there is little to no strategy required for most fights. Adding to this problem is the "nano-forge" which is a very loosely "sci-fi" way of giving your character (and only your character) abilities that basically amount to The Force. Also worth mentioning is the generic A.I voice-in-your-head, named SAM, like every generic A.I should be named, that conveniently gives you all relevant mission objectives.Visually, the game looks great, and runs smoothly even at max settings, including 4K (played using a GTX 1070). Lighting is very well done and provides a gloomy atmosphere with ominous glowing bug silhouettes dashing around and bright energy weapons flashiing across the screen. However, the majority of the time, the lighting is the only thing you'll get to appreciate, since the game is too dark to notice any other visual effects.However, If you can get this game on sale, need something to play in Steam Big Picture mode, and/or want to mow down generic alien bugs in exo-suits, this is a fairly good title. Just ignore the fact that it is supposed to be a red faction game, and dont bother listening to the "story". Just go shoot stuff.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												Pros:+Awesome destructive sandbox propertiesCons:-Drab and boring story mode; linear and ♥♥♥♥♥♥-Not enough content; when you beat it, you're done-No expansive use of it's own boons; blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up! - but don't do anything with itOverall: 5.0/10All this game does is give you the simple - and fun - mechanic of blowing everything up, and watching it crumble, and if you want, you can repair it, and do it all over again.Now, they take that, and do absolutely nothing worthy with it, they throw you into a boring linear storyline with nothing but gunfights with the atlernate objective of blowing a small thing up every now and again to give you the illusion that you can really tear stuff up, and get rewarded.Aside from the storymode, you're given two other game modes to mess around in; the first being Horde mode (Or whatever it is) is where you pit yourself up solo, or even with some friends, to fend out waves and waves of the main enemy of the game. But that's all you really do in it, there's not much else to it, and you're not given anything for accomplishing it. The second is Ruin mode, where your goal is to destroy as much as you can as fast and chaoticly as you can, and even if that sounds like what this game was trying to give you in the first place, it doesn't feel that nice.The weapon and fighting mechanics are just meh as the rest of it, get a few weapon slots for pre-defined weapons, and bang bang, hide to recover health, repeat. There's a few interesting weapon aresenals out there, but nothing that'll keep you hooked. The main enemy of the game is an alien race, but instead of clawing you to death with scythes or anything (which they have), they just shoot spikes at you all day. Again, another illusion of doing something unique, but it just masks the fact that they're all faceless soldier grunts.Even with all this, I never played Guerilla, which I heard was way way WAY better and cooler. Yeah, it probably was.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												This game is finally supported on Steam. The New Save Game button finally works. Steam Devs corrected the problem sometime in Late August. I played through this once over the course of 2 play sessions on Normal difficulty. Here is my review:This is your game if you want...Weak supporting characters.A dumb, pathetic main character.A laughable and forgettable plot.Cheap deaths when your cover is destroyed like tissue paper.One branching path through the game's 8 hour story mode.Enemies that often leap around the environment and don't attack you.Pew pew pew. Hide for 3 seconds. Lather Rinse Repeat.This is not your game if you want...A decently written storyA character you can identify with (He is literally 10x more insufferable than Alec Mason). Guns that you can upgrade. Open World environments.Rewards for fighting on higher difficulty.An explanation for why you're doing what you're doing.Fair challenge.This game tries to combine Borderlands with Half Life, and staples on some Descent for good measure. That might sound awesome, but it does none of these things better than the originals it's trying to emulate. The controls are okay. The mechanics...iffy. Seriously, why does this game give you toys like  two dissintigration rifles, and explosive munitions, then tell you to fight waves of enemies on a rickety catwalk over an INSTADEATH lava pit? Makes no sense AT ALL. It gives you restocking areas, but unless you have clairvoyance and know what kind of enemies you're going to be facing, choosing weapons is pointless. This is a downgrade from RF:G, where you knew what missions you were going to be choosing, and chose weapons to suit.I don't mind games that are challenging. At its core, though...RF:A is out to annoy you. If you manually save your game, you restart at the last checkpoint, so the feature is pointless. You have to reacquire everything you got between the checkpoint and the difficult zone. Things like skill upgrades. Ammo. Weapons. These swaps are not remembered if you die.Ammo balance is strange too. The large chests give you some of every ammo type, while the small boxes tend to give you nothing. Either they're for weapons you're not carrying--the game has way too many--or for weapons you're already full up on. So you either have too much ammo, or not enough.Also why must every female character in the RF universe be pretty much worthless at everything?I think Guerilla is much better. It wasn't trying to be other games. It feels like Armageddon is a missed opportunity. I didn't hate my 10 hours with the game. I just didn't feel like the challenge I was facing was fair or consistent. It was just dumb luck mostly, and grinding through. The story is terrible. Some of the worst sci-fi I've ever seen. I would recommend this game on a bargain, at 5.99 or below. Any more than that, don't waste your time.

												Extremely disappointing game. Didn't get into the first two red factions, but started at Guerilla and wanted to check out how its sequel was going.... I really wish I hadn't. AI hasn't improved since side-scrolling days, enemies standing upright until you walk around the corner then immediately blast your face off, so no element of sneak or suprise, you eventually get bored of peaking so just run around the corner already firing your gun. The difficulty is determined by how many enemies there are, not the skill used to take them down (oh look, there is no cover in this room, I wonder how long it will take for the player to die? Let's cram wave after wave of the same♥♥♥♥♥♥into that room, and to add some "origionality" lets make those waves get slightly harder each time.Also the bosses are freaking dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥and take no skill or brain to complete, it feels like I have a Navi over my shoulder pointing out the big freakin' glowy-ball-stuff that I need to shoot a certian number of times until the boss changes colour or something and I need to repeat the process again, except this time I need to avoid some other attack because he somehow transformed from you shooting his♥♥♥♥♥♥... *spoilers* The story is so unbelievably bland. It starts off fairly positively, which is what made me want to play, however it turned exxtremely quickly into a dumb panto written by a three year old and performed by Kirsten Stewart. THERE IS NO EMOTIONAL VALUE TO ANY OF THE CHARACTERS!!I have already mentioned there will be spoilers so here it is, Mason's girl (friend/acquaintance/random-person-he-just-meets??) dies near the end and all he says is "NOOOO" and carries on just as normal.The ENTIRE game is COMPLETELY RAILROADED, with little to gain from veering from the obvious paths, there is no free-world like its predecessor and I get that because you are in caves, but there is no varation from the story, no side-missions, no backstory, the only option after completing the campaign is to do it all again... And I would rather smash my face onto my keyboard repeatedly whilst listening to Skrillex than put myself through that again.So to conclude: DO NOT GET THIS GAME IT IS A WASTE OF MONEYYou're welcome

												TL;DR: Overall, it's a farily decent game. You have the Red Faction feel with complete and utter environmental carnage, but the storyline seems out of place.Quick and Easy game, even on the highest difficulty.Would overall not recommend. _______Dry Humor on a Dry PlanetI will forever love the little bits of comedy that came around during cinematics/gameplay.Mason: SAM, show me where the bugs are.-SAM gives locations. Mason sees the hive colony-Mason: Buckle up, SAM. This may take a while.SAM: There is no "buckle up" directive in my drive.Mason: -sigh- Just shut up and show me where the bugs are.SAM: Affirmative.It's those little chuckles that get you through it all.However...The story feels wrong (it was half-decent though).- First off, this feels nothing like a Red Faction game. You fought the Ultor Corporation in the first one, Sopot's military in the second, and finally the EDF (military/corporation) in the third. This one just suddenly jumps to aliens. What the hell?There were no hints that I recall in the previous 3 games that even remotely stated aliens were here. They just suddenly exist. I suppose you could say those mutants you fought in RF 1 were a hint, but even then...They were mutants. Animals/humans Kapek experimented on with his nano-tech.Not even (some of) the  journals which tell of events prior/during/post RF 1 still felt right. They seemed out of place, what with their recordings being about aliens and Kapek, rather than something more believable (like Kapek and experimentation on humans/animals they brought (see/play RF 1 for animal/animutant encouters)).__The Destruction is awesomeWhat more can be said? This engine knows how to supply the demand for endless carnage.Whether you use a Magnet, a Hammer or a Rocket, just about everything can and will be blown to bits.It's all so satisfying to see those explosions consume the aliens that won't stay the f**k still.My only gripe is..Oh holy ****, I cant' progress because the place keeps falling apart!Long story short, you will be constantly repairing the entire level you just destroyed. If you don't, you're likely to blow up the bridge you needed to cross to get through the campaign. There's as much repairing as there is destruction, which can get annoying.A variety of abilities to complement the weapons.This game really made me want to use my abilities. I wasn't just firing my weapon, I actually felt encouraged to use my nanoforge's attacks to help maximize my damage, destruction, and survivabilityThe $20 price is around the right area, although getting it for less never hurts. Compared to the other games in the RF Franchise, this was a disappointment for me. That aside, it is a decent playthrough, though not as good as it could have been.All in all, I can't recommend this game, especially if you've played Red Faction: Geurilla.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Red Faction franchise has always been about the one gimmick that made the game so noteworthy; the impressive "Geomod" technology that lets you rework the levels around you. Its odd then that in the latest title of the series Volition seems so reluctant to let me play with this gimmick in any meaningful way. Oh sure, I can bash down buildings and then instantly rebuild them with my "nano-forge" but the structures I take apart are all cosmetic frippery. The core of the game revolves instead around the stock weapons and the endless horde of generic aliens it throws at you. Bereft of the Geomod technology, Red Faction Armageddon is an below-average shooter, with the usual bevy of cliche characters and the standard nonsensical plot (the latter doubtlessly assisted by the fine writers of the SyFy channel, who underwrote this sequel). The graphics - horribly shuttered by a 45 degree FOV - were surprisingly unimpressive for a DirectX 11 game. The only time the game rose from the abyss of mediocrity were in the handful of instances when it opened up a little bit and let me truly experience the effectiveness of the Geomod tech. But these were too infrequent to save the game from its fear of its own uniqueness and by the end of the game I was overwhelmed by overwhelming ennui.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												This is a very solid action game with excellent gameplay, high quality visuals, a large variety of satisfying weapons and destructible environments. Yes, it is linear. No, it is not epically long. If those are big issues for you, then don't get it. Most of the complaints I have read about Armageddon are that it is different from Guerilla. Well, it is. Guerilla is open world, Armageddon is not. Guerilla has lots of driving and combat with vehicles, Armageddon does not. Guerilla also has its share of flaws, and they are different from Armageddon's flaws. In Armageddon, I would have liked more outdoor areas, more human enemies, vehicular enemies, and more large structures to destroy. But despite those shortcomings, it is still a good game.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												My hopes for Armageddon weren't high, which is why it’s taken me so long to actually play the game. I was pleasantly surprised though :)The game is very well made, the environment design, the lighting, the animations and weapon effects. It’s all made to a very high standard, similar to the previous game, Red Faction: Guerrilla. Unlike Guerrilla though, this is a corridor shooter but with some seriously innovative features. Returning from the previous games is the geo-mod technology that allows the player to destroy the environment. I’m so happy they've brought this back and even enhanced it! The new features include a  magnet gun, which allows objects to be pulled into other objects with great force. This creates a gameplay style I’ve never experienced before! Using a house to crush your enemies never gets old! The new nano forge ability allows the player to regenerate the environment after you have destroyed it. This I found particularly cool, destroying the environment and then rebuilding to create cover or access new areas. Clearly a lot of thought has been put into new gameplay features for this game. The story is probably the weakest point here. There are many links to previous Red Faction games (which is always great to see), but the characters are somewhat stale and the story feels as though it’s moving too fast at times. The low res cut scenes don’t help either.But overall, a very good game. It’s always great to experience new and interesting gameplay mechanics, which Armageddon pulls off very well.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This is a short review. I might write a full review sometime later.Anyway, this game is fun and has full destructible/repairable environments. What's not to like? Sure, it's not open world like Red Faction: Guerilla, and it definetly would be better if it was, but it's still heck of a lot of fun. It took me 16 hours to complete the full campaign, which is longer than your average shooter. This game could also do with a bit of variety. Most of the levels look way too similar and throughout the game I was really hoping for more sections on actual land and not underground. The story isn't perfect and does suffer from some cliches, but it's still good and is better than most of what we get from shooters nowadays.When I finished the game (which was about 10-20 minutes ago as of writing this review) I felt a bit disappointed and it did feel lackluster. I expected a bit more of an ending. The game doesn't necessarily end in a cliff hanger, but I felt that the ending could have been more conlcusive.Overall, I enjoyed Guerilla and Armageddon thoroughly and equally (I also remember playing the original Red Faction on the Nokia N-Gage... I know), I honestly really want to see a Red Faction 5. The IP currently belongs to Nordic Games, so Volition, the developers of Red Faction 1-Armageddon (fun fact: also the developers of the Saints Row franchise) will not be working on RF5. Now we can only hope that Nordic Games know what they're doing and will deliver a solid next instalment in the franchise. It would be great if they would try to co-operate with Volition (Volition stated they will not do work on RF anymore, but hey, they could still help). So, good luck, Nordic.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Underneath this seemingly by-the-numbers corridor shooter, lies an outrageously fun and inventive 3rd person shooter.A game extremely ahead of its time in terms of destruction and reconstruction, you not only get to destroy everything you see, including entire vertical levels, you often need to reconstruct what you have destroyed (in an astonishingly fascinating way, using the nano forge) in order to continue on.The graphics start plain, but are increasingly amped up with amazing particle effects and explosions.AI is impressive and works in team effort utilizing the 3d environment to its fullest.The enemies are bugs, and this has been done before (lost planet like), but are graphically done well.Weaponry in the game is some of the most fun I can recall in recent gaming.The Singularity gun is an incredible and gorgeously animated black hole firing weapon.The game even has weapon that is a unicorn that fires rainbow particle beams, anally.  Not kidding, its spectacular and it is real.GPS is well designed and much needed in this maze of level design, albeit very fun and well layed out.The story is well fleshed out, but takes a lot from Bioshock/Borderlands using Audio Logs.Overall this is a far meatier game than Red Faction Guerilla (even if it doesnt have a jet pack... hey its got a spaceship!) and a worthy successor to an already great game.Many people missed this game, probably quitting after the first couple levels, but I assure you, if you salvage, buy weaponry and powerups, you will be waiting for more bugs to pummel with your overpowered weapon rack!8/10, I would have paid more for this one.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												After playing this game, I have played all the RF games, and I can now tell you which one is the worst. It's NOT Red Faction: Armageddon. The worst RF game goes to Red Faction II. Seriously, Armageddon is better than I thought it would be. The story is ok somewhat, but it's better than in RF:G. You play as Darius Mason, grandson of Alec Mason from RF:G, and he has more personality than his grandfather. He can be hilarious at times, especially when interacting with his S.A.M. (Situational Awareness Module) A.I. The theme of revolution is still here, although not as it was in previous games, you'll see what I mean. The campaign last for roughly 15 hours.As for gameplay, it's really fun. Geo-Mod is still here. My main gripe is the removal of open-world. That's really a step back. It could easily have been implemented here. An underground open-world? That would have been great. But I like the new weapons such as the Magnet Gun. It allows you to latch magnets between two objects making one move towards the other. Upgrades are nice too. Taking out the baddies is really fun. What I really didn't like is how the game holds your hand. Not only do you have an objective marker, but also an arrowed path telling you where to go, leaving no room to find where to go on your own. And during boss fights, there is an icon telling you where you shoot, such as weak spots. Too-much hand-holding! As for Infestation mode, I haven't really played it yet, but it's a Horde mode, where you fight endless waves of enemies. Sounds fun.In the end, RF:A isn't bad, but it could have been better. Back when it was released, it would be worth a rental, but buying it now wouldn't be a bad idea, since it's relatively cheap nowadays. Now, Nordic games has control of the franchise, and they have promised a new game. Well, let us see how that turns out...

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												now it says 0 hours for this game but i played it on console while i had PC repairs done and the only reason i have this game in my library is that it came in a humble bundle and all the other titles were decent but getting to the point ....just ...wow... to date this has to be not the worst game i have ever played but definitely the worst sequel. i mean it was never going to be an easy task living up to the standards set by the games predecessor Red Faction: Guerrilla but whoever was leading the Dev team for this game had clearly either never played the first game or was doing so blindfolded and with noise cancelling earphones on. the list of issues i have with this game makes it difficult to know where to begin.okay so Armageddon is a linear third person shooter set in the Red Faction universe. the game follows the great grandson of Alex Mason (the Hero of the first game) named Darius Mason. Darius is a soldier in the Red Faction army who now rule mars after the events of the first game but after a monumental screw up on his part humanity is left living underground unable to survive on the surface of mars. the story to this game is many things and none of them good, its generic, poorly paced, poorly written and has a penchant for making scenes appear dramatic when you can blatantly see them coming. it even has a love interest side story to it (totally not trying to copy and paste from the first game) which gets a fittingly poor ending to it. its not the worst writing i have ever laid eyes on but its damn close to it. they say if you gave a thousand monkeys type writers and left them alone they would eventually type out the complete works of Shakespeare.. this game is what the monkeys typed out.down to the core of this game, the mechanics .. now despite my disliking for this game the mechanics are one of the few things that this game actually got correct. gun mechanics work perfectly as expected, movement is smooth with no issues and in general the games mechanics are as solid as Armageddons (there is a god after all). this is a rare redeeming feature in a sea of disaster. the only real issues you could have with the mechanics would be during the flight mission when the ship does control a bit like you are having a seizure at the wheel but  other than this instance they are fine. the best part of this game which i very much believe they just copied over from the first game is the destruction engine (i shudder to imagine if they had redone this aspect as well) the engine is great providing seamless destruction of cover and environments. this is the best part of this game just being able to blow up or disintegrate the cover preventing you from slaying the enemy (be warned this works both ways) and i did quite enjoy this diamond among the rough feature after the hours of endless fun you get from it in the first game.back to whats wrong with this game then. its a LINEAR sequel to a SANDBOX game ... how hard did the games developers hit each other over the head with a hammer to think this would work. look at any successful sandbox game such as Grand Theft Auto or Saints row ... imagine they had a linear sequel ... it just doesn't work .. this kind of game is meant to be played as a sandbox. this very story driven linear progression also hampers the range of missions the player has access to. in the first game the player conducted a wide range of mission in order to advance, now though the levels can be summarized by starting each mission and being told .. follow this line and kill everything in your path. there is no diversity it is just a repeated slog of go here run this way and kill this thing. there is also NOTHING but story in this game, no side missions except for collecting a few audio logs left in blatantly obvious places throughout the game. the first game had a wide variety missions and activities set aside from the main campaign. why would you develop a game and then remove all the content for the sequel? its just stupid really. the linear environments also have a negative affect on combat. no more flanking the enemy or sniping from afar no for this game you just have to slug it out in toe to toe combat 90% of the time unless that specific part of the game requires the use of a sniper or other specialist weapon. because we totally hated having the diverse arsenal of weapons available at any point in the previous game .. thanks THQ you are a real star .. NOTand now we have the multiplayer.. what can i say for this other than DON'T!!.. the multiplayer for this game is almost as terrible as the single player with majority of the issues from the core game crossing over into the multiplayer. to simplify it you have two modes a mode for destruction where player stake it in turn to see who can cause the most destruction in a map and a kind of horde mode where the player stares down waves of aliens hoping not to become E.Ts Dinner. the destruction mode is pretty fun to begin with but there is again not much diversity to it and it gets pretty boring pretty quickly. the horde mode lasts a bit longer with more maps and a better experience if your playing with other players but again its just the same thing over and over and over .. the maps are okay but the AI for the aliens is shoddy at best. sometimes they wont even notice you when you stand in front of them or on the flip side they will spot you from a mile away and bring all their little buddies to tear your martian nads right off (funny when watching it happen.... not so funny when it happened to me :( ). its a great laugh if you are playing it every now and again or in split screen but it doesn't last. the hype for this game actually quite excited me at the time and i (regrettably) pre-ordered this game thinking it would be as awesome as the first game ... i was wrong. in short this game is a less than enjoyable experience. the linear, poorly written generic story and tedious gameplay coupled with the poor multiplayer experience and community make this a game i wouldn't be in a hurry to play again. despite the redeeming features of the amazing destruction engine and all around good mechanics for this game they are twinkling plus points in the sea of disaster that is this game. in short .. if you buy this game after reading this you probably have a power drill or some other sharp object jammed in the side of your head O_o in which case you probably loved the ending to RAGE and live on the moon..

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Despite the fact that I have never played any of the other Red Faction games, I love this title. The story is very captivating and I love the large array of weapons that you can choose from. This game seems to always keep me on my feet, shooting aliens here, one there, it is constantly making me energetic. I have only put 2 hours into the game and I have only reached 20% of the entire story mode, which means that there is a fairly long story. Even after I get done with the single player campaign, there is 2 OTHER multi-player modes that I can play. The graphics look very crisp and nice. I like how (most) the world is fully destructable, using my Maul I can tear down walls or any various obsticles that stand in my way. I will probably find myself playing this game when I complete it again because this is a very nice title. I am concidering playing the other Red Faction games because people have said that this was the game that ruined the entire series. I don't know what made this game so much worse for the Red Faction series. I like to play shooters and adventure titles, this was a very nice game for me to pick up, it is a 3rd person action adventure shooter title that takes place in the future years. I am not extremely far in the story yet so I don't exactly have a really good standpoint as to what's going on in the game's storyline. I would reccomend this to someone who hasn't played any other Red Faction titles because it seems to me that Red Faction players seem to hate this game. The game really doesn't seem that repetative to me, but sometimes it can be. It's not as bad as Dead Island but it can get that way sometimes. I don't die normally, I have only died once and that was on accident. I have the difficutly at Normal setting so if it were me, I'd set it to hard or something above Normal for someone looking for a little harder AI to fight against. I'd give this game a rough 8.9/10 it's a great title if you want a 3rd person shooter kind of like Gears of War.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												Underwhelming is what can best be used to describe this game. There's nothing wrong with it save for some optimization issues. The only things "wrong" I found were the aesthetics and that is, of course, debatable. The Red Faction just looks wrong, to me. They look silly all shaved bald and running around in capes. Their technology looks just plain wrong. It looks terrible and boring. Even the vaunted destruction physics are utilized poorly. Driving a tank through a wall never felt so boilerplate. And the enemies are even worst. Who honestly thought that using monsters would be a good idea? The Religious zealots you fight look ridiculous. They look like rejects from a GI Joe cartoon and act like it, too. It all looks like they were made to market a toy line.But, is there anything wrong with it other than that? Not really, it's solid, sure. It's just so unimpressive. Sure, there's fun to be had bashing down walls to kill enemies, that's definitely a high point. But, really? That's it. A forgettable plot, boring weapon mechanics and an underutilized destruction engine.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												The sales of Red Faction: Armageddon were poor and the game was considered a commercial failure by THQ. Because of this, on June 27, 2011, THQ announced that plans for future installments had been cancelled. The disappointing sales of Armageddon, along with other factors, had led THQ to lose $38.4 million in a fiscal year. While no actual sales figures are revealed, after THQ declared bankruptcy in December 2012, developer Volition, who was purchased by Deep Silver in an auction, revealed that the development of both Red Faction Guerrilla and Red Faction: Armageddon had "lost quite a bit" of money" for THQ.

content:
Posted: February 10
												The only downfall of this title is the fact that it claims to be a "Red Faction" game.Red Faction Armageddon is actually a very good game.It would probably be better if they didn't use the "Red Faction" franchize name.There is very little Faction work.I've heard people complain about how Darius (the protagonist) isn't a likeable character, and that he is just a generic shooter hero.  Well this is true, He is just generic. A hero who falls in love, takes her on his journey, she is killed by the alien queen, Darius goes head first into the hive, and kills every last one of them.Now, the Aresonal is uninspired bull feces (aside from mister toots).There are only a few carry-over weapons from Red Faction Guerilla.Just to name a few, we have The Arc Welder, The Nano Rifle, and The Enforcer.The rest of the weapons are uninspired reduxes from other games and boring reskins from older entries in the series.Don't get me wrong, this is a fun game, but it isn't Red Faction.With that being said, this game is very fun.There isn't an overbearing narative to weigh down an alien-head smashing party.You can destroy entire buidings, and then repair them in a blink of the eye.You can kill so many aliens, even with other aliens (refering to the magnet gun).Well, I can't reccomend this game if you want a Red Faction game, but if you want a high-action alien killing,building destroying sandbox game, this is the game for you.With Love,FaustOh, just a personal note, You Matter...Unless you multiply yourself by the speed of light squared, then you energy.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I was really hoping that this game would further explore the avenues opened by Red Faction Guerrilla, a game I have come back to over and over just because of the fun and lively open world setting, combined with the absolute joy of destroying stuff. Armageddon still has the wonderful knocking down of buildings, and the magnet gun is incredibly fun to play with, but it just feels like puttering around with little point, compared to the fun of kicking over a UEF hornets nest, trying to desperately knock down a barracks before you are overwhelmed by soldiers or are forced to make a desperate getaway. It was too much of a feeling of being a corridor shooter, after having gotten used to the open and large scale of the previous game. I enjoyed it a little at first, but I quickly got bored and never finished it. Maybe it gets better?

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												You gotta be kidding me. I played the first couple of levels thinking, "Okay, eventually we are going to hit the open world like in Red Faction Guerilla and THEN blow a few buildings up." Instead, this game is a hallway shooter and mostly underground, no less. Sure, you get to destroy      some equipment with a couple rather nifty weapons (and repair them in case you're a drunken idiot and dissolved that one catwalk you needed to cross) but its all within the confines of a dank, uninteresting atmosphere. You'd have more fun going down into your grandmother's cellar and knocking a shelf over. There is what's known as Ruin Mode where you can run around and turn the map into a parking lot but that becomes a snorefest eventually. The story is borderline laughable. Not cringeworthy but it's like the vice president of the company's son wrote it for his drama class. This isn't a horrible game. Get it if it's on sale. If you have a choice, get the very first Red Faction and Guerilla. Skip the 2nd.

YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Red Faction: Armageddon' (GeForce GT 640)

			You can get the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/55110 A non-biased quick look @ 'Red Faction: Armageddon' - When the massive Terraformer that supplies Mars with its Earth-like air and...		

When the massive Terraformer that supplies Mars with its Earth-like air and weather is destroyed, the atmosphere turns to chaos, super-tornados and lightning storms engulf the planet. To survive, the Colonists flee to the underground mines and build a network of habitable caves. Five years later, Darius Mason, grandson of Martian Revolution heroes Alec Mason and Samanya, runs a lucrative business from Bastion, underground hub of Colonist activity. Mining, scavenging, mercenary work--if the job is dangerous, Darius is your man. Few sane people now venture to the ravaged surface, aside from contractors like Darius and the smugglers who run goods between the settlements. When Darius is tricked into reopening a mysterious shaft in an old Marauder temple, he releases a long-dormant evil and unleashes Armageddon on Mars. As Colonist and Marauder settlements are torn asunder, only Darius and the Red Faction can save mankind. The battle will take them across the storm-blasted planet--and below it, to the very heart of the unspeakable threat. Red Faction®: Armageddon™ expands on the critically acclaimed, best-selling franchise with new, groundbreaking challenges. You are humanity’s last hope for survival. - Highly Recommended!

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Awsome game. Throw bugs at other bugs to kill bugs or throw buildings at bugs to kill bugs or throw bugs at buildings to kill buildings or do it all at once!The magnet gun is the best gun in any game ever.The level destruction is the star of the game and it is very good. It is limited to manmade structures and crystals.The main campaign is a little short at just under 6 hours long and even that felt a little dragged out towards the end. It suffers from very repetetive gameplay in the second half of the game. It is occasionally eased a little when you are given a mech or vehicle but those are too few and far between.There is a bit of replayability where you unlock a whole set of new weapons and "cheats" to use in new game+ unlocked with salvage the same way as abilities.You have 4 active abilities seperate from weapons, a force push, an aoe stun/damage/lifesteal, a shield and a beserk mode. Because the conventional weapons are boring and you rarely fight enmies with guns the beserk and shield are pretty much useless unless your going full mele. The AOE lifesteal upgrade is pretty much required as there isnt really a way to avoid most attacks as they are either to fast, AOE or mele.There are two other modes outside of the campaign:Infestation is a 1-4 player co-op wave defense. You and your allies must defend against increasingly difficult waves of bugs, nothing special there. You will not find anyone else online unless its a free weekend or somthing, be sure to bring friends if you want to play this mode.(I forgot what this is called, lets call it destruction) Destruction puts in a small map with goal of causing as much destruction as possible within the time limit. You have all your weapons and ulocked upgrades from the campaign. There is also a freeplay mode that removes the time limit and lets you use cheats and the op weapons unocked for completing the campaign.Overall this is a fun little game with awsome mechanics i wish other games picked up. I cannot reccomend it at full price with such little content, but definetly pick it up on a sale or free weekend.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Red Faction: Armageddon is a game developed by Volition Studios and originally published by the now defunct company THQ, now published by THQ Nordic (or Nordic Games) and is also the fourth game in the Red Faction series Red Faction: Armageddon is an action packed third person shooter which follows up from the previous Red Faction: Guerrilla game and continues the Red Faction story line. However, this time the game sticks with the third person view from Red Faction: Guerrilla and also drops the open world concept and is linear like the first original two gamesThe storyline and missions are still fun as ever and works out well even though the amazing open world from Red Faction: Guerrilla is gone. The gameplay is pretty standard, but lots of fun and you also have a new nifty magnet gun and some powers with the Nano ForgeOnce again the highlight of the Red Faction series is blowing stuff up, and you can blow up all the structures and also repair things since enemies will often be attacking you and stairs and other things you need to access will be gone. Lastly, there's an Infestion (Horde) mode which is tons of fun where you have to stay alive and fend off all of the enemiesOverall, this game is a lot of fun and is not like the previous game, however for what it is - you'll have a blast playing by blowing things up and fighting off evil cultist and aliens RECOMMENDED :)

												If you liked the original Red Faction titles because of their open worlds, faction system, and replayability; skip this at all costs!!RF:Armageddon is merely an on-rails console port that has nothing in common with the original games in the franchise except detailed destruction, a few of the original weapons, and the Red Faction name.The story is very uninteresting, and the dialog is just horrid. Everything smells of console trash; from the magic floating arrows over anything of interest, to the designated checkpoints, to the on-rails approach of each mission (i.e. cunscene after cutscene). There are NO factions - 99% of the game is fighting aliens, not the EDF or any other factions. There is no free-roam; with very small corridors and caves that have the all too familliar checkpoint system that makes you reload over and over and over until you finish it.In the spirit of the earlier RF titles, I can't recommend this game at all, unless you just want another mediocre console shoot-em-up.5/10

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Since its release, THQ and Volition have done everything in their power to try and bring people back to the Red Faction series with very little avail. When you make a game that is a smash success it has to be hard to replicate that success in the form of sequels, which were obviously created, but were a major bust in the eyes of people who actually followed the games since day one including myself.Volition's fourth attempt in the series is coined Red Faction: Armageddon. Now the subtitle may be a reference to where the story intends to go within the game, but it would also be a good way to describe the game itself. The story begins on Mars in the distant future; just like all others have before it. You play as Darius Mason; a Red Faction member and the grandson of Alec Mason who was the protagonist in Red Faction: Guerrilla in the year 2120. 50 years have passed since the liberation of colonies from the Earth Defense Force. As Darius, you must face off against a new enemy who is trying to destroy stability on the planet and make it uninhabitable to humans. By using terrorist attacks on the Terraformer which provides oxygen and atmosphere to the planet, he is slowly succeeding. The man responsible for all of this is known as Adam Hale. Adam is a cultist leader for the Marauders. This group of mercenaries was converted by him into his own personal army.After the attack on the Terraformer, you are led to believe that Adam was killed during the explosion which brought the Terraformer crumbling to the ground. Everyone with common sense or awareness of the cliches which are in nearly all movies and games can already tell exactly where this is headed within the first 10 minutes of play. Everyone has been forced underground as a result of these events, which have made the surface of the planet a wasteland. Violent storms, lack of oxygen and mega tornados are what greet people at the surface so obviously a great deal of this game will take place in a linear underground environment. While all the population of Mars is being forced under the surface, a deadly plague strikes which is killing everyone. It is your job to find out what has caused this and who is responsible.In terms of the story, it is hardly anything riveting or interesting for that fact; and leaves you wondering why you are even playing the game at all. From the beginning, you know exactly where things are going, no suspense, no mystery, just destroy everything and kill everyone until it ends. If you have played the original Red Faction, you will find yourself again questioning this game. What does this really have to do with the first game? Why are people still on Mars if everything has been so terrible three times before? The last but not least; why is everyone trying to either destroy the planet or control it in a totalitarian fashion? Obviously it has worked out so great three previous times why not give it another shot; 4th times a charm right? This series has become a joke. They took something pure and perfect then ruined it by changing the formula until nearly every identifiable shred of the original game no longer existed.These problems started mainly with Guerrilla, carry over into Armageddon, which added a few more to boot. For the love of god choose a camera and stick to it. The series went from First Person, to a Third Person 360° viewable camera to now a Third Person shoulder locked camera; like I said earlier, formula destroyed. Geo-Mod 2.0-2.5 are again a step in the wrong direction, in the original game you could destroy practically everything, including terrain to make your own paths or find ways around obstacles. This has been severely dialed back, and I am not even sure how it can be dignified with a version 2.0 or 2.5 branding aside from it being the engine name. The only things which can be destroyed are man-made objects, no terrain. While the destruction is impressive, it is all ruined by shooting a wall and not even a scratch showing up.Hold onto your pants because the bad does not stop there. Where are all the vehicles you could pilot in all previous games? There are vehicles all over this game but none you can drive? Really? It's kind of a slap in the face to be honest, but this comes back to changing the formula. However, they did make a wise decision and reverted back to the roots of the game being linear. The whole Red Faction/Grand Theft Auto open world concept that Guerrilla attempted to do was just too weird and turned a lot of people off; that would explain their logic for Armageddon.After reading all that is wrong with it let's get to some things which are good and alright. The game looks fantastic in nearly every way, crisp textures, DirectX 11 effects and amazing use of physics on the destruction, the presentation is overall great. With the nice boost in visuals you will also notice some new modes, features and an updated arsenal of weapons. There are two new modes, and they are incorporated very well. The first mode is Ruin. You have a set time to destroy the most structures possible and must obtain a certain score to achieve the next level. There is some replayability to this, but it is stunted by the lack of total levels. The second mode which has been incorporated is Infestation, it is similar to Nazi zombies in CoD and Killing Floor.You must kill wave after wave of enemies on each level. Some are purely survival and others are defense so you must protect structures from being destroyed. Each level has up to 30 waves to survive. This works out great and is a fun way for friends to play whether it be through the Internet or Lan; there is a lot of replayability here. Conventional multiplayer is something that has been scraped completely, for how this game is I think that was a smart move. If it were still a first-person shooter it would need this to compete with the others; but as it stands it's not something necessary.The game play is fun in its own right. Very standard Third Person Shooter combat mixed with a Gears of War type cover system. What it does, it does fairly well but the mediocrity of it makes you feel as if you have played this game before. The mix of weapons keeps things pretty interesting. You have a choice of about 10 weapons ranging from just your standard shotgun all the way up to a singularity cannon which creates black holes and engulfs nearby structures. Using the varied weapons can be fun and finding new ways to kill or destroy with them is mainly what the game is about.Probably the biggest highlight to the entire game is the Path to War DLC. This takes place hours before the events which bring down the Terraformer. The great thing about this is it allows you to actually use the vehicles and play as both sides. It definitely gives a fresh perspective to the game. I would recommend playing this before starting the campaign. With about 45 minutes of game play this makes for an overall nice addition to the game, but I don't think it is exactly worth the money.All in all, Red Faction: Armageddon is not a terrible game on its own. I hope that is not something I conveyed here. It is a terrible game in terms of it living up to the original which can be said about Red Faction 2 & Guerrilla also, but for what they all do, comparisons aside, they are interesting gaming experiences on their own. If you are looking for a game with deep story, gameplay which is enthralling from beginning to end or something that you will have fond memories of as you get older; this game is not for you. If you want a game which is fun to jump into and blow things up periodically for 20 to 30 minutes at a time without paying attention to what is really going on; this is absolutely for you. Consider it a destruction simulator with a cliched and somewhat boring story to go with it, and you will have the time of your life.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												I got this game from one of the HBs and all I knew about it is "You get to destroy a lot of stuff". So one day I decided to download it because I wanted to play something different and of course wreck things. The game looks really good, the physics are awesome and what is in my opinion the best thing about the game - it really understands when to deliver new content to you as a player. Small interjection - you have a huge maul to kill people and destroy buildings, so in case you are not convinced imagine yourself jumping around Mars (gravity is way lower than on Earth!) delivering head smashes to your enemies. The game features variety of weapons, enemies and upgrades. The story is logical and well-tied together, it is funny and maybe not greatly engaging or original but it can defend itself good enough. All in all I recommend this game for everyone who a) wants to destroy stuff for the sake of destroying stuff b) wants to be surprised about what the game lets you do c) is looking for a non-open world game d) wants to play the game like he wants with the tools he is given, not boxed in with two alternatives Game says I spend 6 hours 37 minutes in campaign mode on Hard. I thought it was a lot more (steam says so as well) so I guess the game sucked me in pretty hard.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												I found this third person shooter a lot of fun. I've never played any of the other Red Factions, and am told that some of them (if not all) had a more open world feel compared to this much more linear adventure. However, I think its average metacritic score of 70 odd suffers from these sorts of comparisons, as it's a pretty enjoyable game in its own right without any previous experience with the rest of the franchise.There are a decent range of weapons that can float different people's boats, but I settled into my favourite four pretty quickly - the magnet gun, sniper rifle, mace (for up close and personal squishing), & a heavy damage weapon (which was the plasma cannon for a long time, rocket launcher, and then finally the singularity cannon). The best thing about the game however, is how much of the environment is destructable. It can break from enemy attack, your own attack, or you can even use it to harm enemies (particularly with the magnet gun). It's honestly one of the best features of the game, and using your particle repairer, you can build up most of the destroyed environment to destroy or throw at enemies again!Replayability may be a little sticking point however. Like I mentioned the single player is quite linear though can obviously be replayed. However, there are another two gamemodes, one of which can be multiplayer. The first is ruin which is essentially using all your best skills at destroying as much of the destructible environment in the map you're put on. There's a short time limit and points are earned on how much damage you do and at what efficiency. You essentially need to destroy X amount of points to complete the few different maps they have and can continue to try set bigger scores. However, it feels like just the addon it is rather than a completely different game mode. The second is Infestation, which is essentially defeating waves of enemies which get progressively harder (up to 20 waves per map). You can solo this or play with other people, with some similarities to that game mode in Gears of War. I'm not sure about whether or not you spawn more enemies when you play with other people compared to solo though (as I haven't played multiplayer), but I'd hope so given I was able to handle most things solo with just the magnet gun and a decent position on the map playing it smart. The better of the two additional gamemodes for sure, but only extends replayability a little bit more.Well worth the money I paid for it in a humble bundle. The entire red faction collection (which this game is included with) is still available both from the Humble store and here on steam (I think).

												I got this game from one of the HBs and all I knew about it is "You get to destroy a lot of stuff". So one day I decided to download it because I wanted to play something different and of course wreck things. The game looks really good, the physics are awesome and what is in my opinion the best thing about the game - it really understands when to deliver new content to you as a player. Small interjection - you have a huge maul to kill people and destroy buildings, so in case you are not convinced imagine yourself jumping around Mars (gravity is way lower than on Earth!) delivering head smashes to your enemies. The game features variety of weapons, enemies and upgrades. The story is logical and well-tied together, it is funny and maybe not greatly engaging or original but it can defend itself good enough. All in all I recommend this game for everyone who a) wants to destroy stuff for the sake of destroying stuff b) wants to be surprised about what the game lets you do c) is looking for a non-open world game d) wants to play the game like he wants with the tools he is given, not boxed in with two alternatives Game says I spend 6 hours 37 minutes in campaign mode on Hard. I thought it was a lot more (steam says so as well) so I guess the game sucked me in pretty hard.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												This game started out promising, it looks fairly good, there's a great magnet gun that is fun to use, everything can be destoryed and reparied, and the lighting was good.  And for the first few hours everything seemed good, but after that it all starts to fall apart.  The story starts to become boring, with little to keep you interested, the characters are not memorable, and by the end of the game you just don't care what happens.  Halfway through the campaign everything starts to feel drawn out and some objectives fell like they were put in just to add extra play time, you actually reach a point where it would make sense for the game to end and wrap things up, but the game pushes on, and it does that 3 or 4 times in the closing stages.  The last 2 hours of the game had me fustrated that it hadn't ended, it was annoying to continue playing, and don't think you're rewarded with a brilliant ending.  The combat also takes its toll the longer you play, the destructable items and terrain become a pain, occasionally you get stuck on areas and have to rely on random jumping to get you out of situations, you end up constantly reparing the way you need to go as AI seems to shoot at that more that you.  The magnet gun which pulls terrain from one point to another is fun to use at first and probably the most effective gun in the game, but no othe weapon brings anything different to the table, which means using those make this anothe generic shooter.Overall this game is boring as hell.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Although this game was fairly linear it was still an action packed romp.  Good story, decent visuals, a host of weapons to use, and a variety of ways to play.  This is *nothing* like RF:Guerrilla with the open world.  This whole story is on tracks, but that's not entirely a bad thing.  There's some exploration to be done to find things, but you always have to "get back on the rails" to get the story moving again.  You can upgrade weapons and abilities using the ever familiar scrap which makes for some progression.  As you play, after you've unlocked your core upgrades (or before), you can unlock features using scrap that can be used on future playthroughs.  Many would consider these cheats (super weapons, unlimited ammo, etc), but if you've played through the game and story already, some of the features are great fun (like Mr. Toots) and you can choose what you want to use and not use.  In this way, you could supplement a boring section of the game with a super weapon, just to make it fun.  I never used unlimited ammo; it's just an option if you like that sort of thing.Best game ever?  No.Great fun?  Certainly :)

												Simply amazing game, especially for its age. There's not much to say about this except for its amazing physics engine awesome weaponry neat skillsets to evolve and simply dynamic, destructive and downright ridiculous enemies you face. From simply taking on the cultists to fighting a massive ever expanding army of mutating bugs from deep underground. I played this game in its entirety in one go because I just couldn't put it down. The controls are simple and easy to get used to. Not to mention once beating the game you unlock Mr. Toots a unicorn that shoots vaporizing rainbows from its posterior. I am going to play through this game on a harder difficulty just to enjoy it a second time because not very many other games you play offer such great playthrough value like this game with destructive powers and weaponry you can just smash everything just to rebuild it and smash it again. Along with all that you get to operate several awesome "walkers" that allow you to mow down enemies with homing rockets, giant lasers, some kind of electricity weapon, and crushing them with your sheer size and smash ability. I give this game a 10/10 and couldn't find a way to make it better than it already is besides making another one.

												Give a man a massive enviroment filled with beauty and he will admire it. Give him an arsenal of weapons with creative ways and he will destroy it. This utilizes the concept of if it isn't nailed into the floor it can be obliterated, though if it is nailed down you can magnitize it out and then destroy it. This is the first ever RF game I played and I totally enjoyed every second of it. It has a intelligent way of knowing when too much is enough; throwing you into new enviroments with new obstacles before you have a chance of getting bored. It does lack the major politcal undertone that the series is supposedly known for, unless I missed it, aswell as the Free Roaming objectives that I was told was present in the predecessors. It reminded me a lot fo Jak and Daxter which made the gameplay more enjoyable, though at times it seemed like a drag between point A and B with constant repeative objectives instead of plot. The creativeness of the weapons and power you have makes this game worth whatever the asking price is.

												This game is underrated... The single biggest complaint from other people is that it's "not enough like the older games because of the aliens. Why'd they add aliens?" Really, that complaint just shows that the people criticizing it for that haven't actually played anything but Red Faction Guerrilla (which itself was a great game, btw). Red Faction 1 had aliens, and in fact many of the aliens in RFA look like modernized versions of the RF1 aliens. Additionally, RF1 was linear, just like this game. Like it or hate it, RFA is more like the older games in the series, not less, and it's not some sort of betrayal or unfounded design design.On another note, the game is well optimized, good looking (I find the screenshots actually undersell it in most places), and has responsive gameplay. The series' signature destruction is also intact, so the switch back to linear gameplay hasn't changed much in that regard.It does get tedious after a while, and may not hold up to a second playthrough (keep that in mind when you're deciding how much you're willing to pay), but it's worth the current price of $20 to people who've played other Red Faction Games.

												Much better than its reputation. The aesthetics and writing are B-tier, but the destruction, the weapons, the powers, and the reconstruction ability are really good, better than anything of the sort I have seen in a shooter before. It's just that destruction is not often an end in itself. The first level gives you a misleading impression because you don't have weapons or abilities suited to destruction yet. Anyway having just completed all four Red Faction games back to back I rank them something like this:  3 >>> 4 >>>>>>>>>> 2 >>>>> 1. The first one was the only one I didn't enjoy.

												It's not Guerrilla, but that's not a pro or con, just a difference. Armageddon is a very linear game, void of any of the usual little side missions found in sandbox games. I happen to prefer this, but that's obviously just a personal opinion.There is far less focus on demolition, as combat in this game is more fleshed out. Guns feel much better, and unlocking the enemy healthy indicator really adds to the weight of the shots. You also now have abilities that you can unlock and upgrade from your nano forge.  The game also introduces a repair mechanic, which is neat, if not a little underused. I thought the humor in this game was great. Definitely something I liked over Guerrilla, where the intended humorous dialogue was one-sided and overall more serious.All in all, Armageddon was enjoyable, if not a little short. The difficulty is certainly a step up from Guerrilla, but I didn’t find it very difficult to overcome, and thought it was a good choice to make to go along with the linear path.

												Intro:I got intruduced to the red faction series with RF: 3 and was inpressed woth the open world dynamic. Going into Armegeddon I was worried that the games more linear level structure would be a hard sell.Negatives: I was unfortunately proved right on this, the plot is decidedly shallow and straightforward. It incorperated many of the tropes included in a zombie game, and mixes them into the red faction stew to produce a game that is untimatley dissapointing. The linear structure of the game makes the destruction engine less relivant, and the plot struccles to hold attention. You could feasable play through the entire game without knocking a building down, except where you are requred to destroy something. Levels fell long and often fell clostraphobic, with many redundant fights that struggle to contribute anything new. Certan bugs have to be killed in specific ways, while others are effectively bullet sponges whose soul peopose is to maul you before you can empty enough rounds into the target. Vehicle combat is almost non existant, there are only three vehicles that are useable in the base campign, and all two are used on levels that dont let you get in or out. While you get involved in large spaces within the campign, they can be tedious to cross and ultimately become boring. The in games sound bites you recover do enrich the experience, and they imply a grand conspiracy as to why the world was allowed to collapse in game. The conspiracy narrative never really gets flushed out, and there are entire levels that could be cut out without having any effect on the plot. For example, the level where you fight the bug queen fells like filler once you actually beat the game and discover that fight (and the death of your girlfriend) was not even nessary because you could have repaired the terraformer and killed the bugs and any point before the point where the game allows you to do so. Replayability is encouraged by the salvage mechanisim, which carries your upgrades over to multiplayer. Of course, the campign struggles after one playthrough, and it makes other playthroughs feel like a real grind, especally when you have to trade large amounts of salvage to unlock the games array of cheats. The disadvantage  to the salvage system is that you have to play through the campign to stand a chance in multiplayer, because the base player stats are pathetic in comparision. You hold less ammo, reload slower, have ferer hit points, and no nano abilites. Veteran players will steamroll you, then scrape you off the street and beat you into a fine pulp before tbagging you all the way into the respawn que.Positives:The repair mechanic is a cool idea, and was desparately needed in this games prequel, since that envirnment never regenerates. The nano powers you can accumulate through collecting salvage add a fun dynamic that becomes critical in later levels, it struggles to overcome the eventual grind that later levels become though. Griphics have been tuned up, though not by much. Building destruction is smoother thatn in the previous game, but its hard to notice because most weapons make the pillers and colums you hit vanish rather than get blown off. However, when you do get the chance to conventally blow up a building it looks awesome. Multiplayer can keep you interested, but its a personl intrest thing.At its current price I dont recommend it, I managed to get it as part of the RF pack over the thanksgiving sale and so paid a lot less. The game was worth waht I paid for at its sale price, but I would recommend waiting for the price of the game to come down under five dollars before diving into this.

												If you played Guerrilla, you're probably here for another taste of Martian destructive chaos. Armegeddon is a very mixed bag when it comes to pleasing fans of its predecessor, but all in all I think it's *just* worth the money.Yes, you shoot things in this game, but let's ignore that trivial matter and get to what we're all interested in: blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up. Armegeddon's destruction engine is noticably different to Guerrilla's, in that destroying things is much easier. The internal supports in buildings smash as soon as something hits them, so everything breaks with ease. Smashing things in Armageddon is fast, simple, and satisfying.The weapons. Whoever designed the weapons in this game is a god. We are talking nanite grenades, disintegration rays, plasma flamethrowers and the famous wall-weaponising Magnet Gun. And remember the almighty Singularity Bomb from Guerrilla? The one that was so powerful they didn't let you select it from a safehouse? That's a cannon now. You can shoot black holes at people. That is how amazing the guns in this game are. If someone wants to port these to every other Red Faction game ever made, that'll be fine by me.The game also gives you the ability to repair structures at any time, and as you see fit. It is MUCH faster than Guerrilla's Reconstructor, and it allows you to shoot repair grenades later on. I find repairing things relaxing and cathartic, and this title lets me do it whenever I please.The fact this is a linear shooter offputs a lot of people, and I can see why. The focus of the game is regrettably not these glorious modes of mayhem, but shooting aliens! Original! While the gunplay is fun enough, the levels can be very restrictive as far as getting to the breakables is concerned, but just going along for the ride, and the somewhat cheesy story, will have you annihilating plenty. Anyway, you can always manually save the good bits for later smashing. Don't worry though, Wrecking Crew makes a return in the form of Ruin Mode. It's pretty basic - five maps, no settings except a time trial mode or free play - but marked improvements are infinite ammo, four weapon wheel, changing guns at any time, resetting the map without leaving and the aforementioned repair function. There's also a co-op survival mode. 'Sgood. The one giant, monolithic problem with this game is that it crashes. A lot. Like, really a ♥♥♥♥ing lot. At random times when reaching a checkpoint, the game will crash. You will not activate the checkpoint before it crashes, which means doing the whole section again. It destroys the flow of the game like no bug has ever done before. Nordic, please fix this. Now. Overall, it's alright. It's not Guerrilla, but its improved destruction, pleasing graphics, and outrageously fun weapons just about offset the linear format, terrible port and predictable story. Grab this - on sale if you can - if you want to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, and don't care what it takes to get to blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up.

												Not bad but not great.This is one of the more "video-gamey" 3rd person shooters i've played. It's very linear compared to it's predecessor RFG, but it maintains much of the destructibility of the scenery, with even more awesome guns like plasma cannons, lasers, and even a black hole generator.The plot is simple and predictable. Approximately 0 feels were felt throughout any of the story, and just as many craps were given as to what would happen next.Sometimes you need to play a game that involves getting in a massive alien walker and going on a destructive rampage across an alien planet.The aliens are hardly innovative, with little Zerglings rushing you, Hydralisks throwing spines from far away, Nydus Worms sending hordes of monsters at you until you kill them, Ultralisks that rush you and smack you around until they blow up, and Spore Cannons that spread Creep that buffs all the aliens while shooting giant balls of Kool-Aid at you. Not to mention the Queen who has several weak points that you have to hit while dodging adds, fire breath, and grabbing ammo from all the guns that just happen to be lying around.Graphics? Pretty damn amazing.Replayability? Nah, you unlock pretty much everything one time through.I recommend this game, but I'm absolutely on the fence. I got it on sale with the Red Faction pack, so it was definitely worth all the hours i got out of Guerilla, but as for Armageddon, don't buy it unless it's on sale. Overally it was kinda boring, but still worth the play.5/10 would pay 25cents to play an arcade game again

												Not bad but not great.This is one of the more "video-gamey" 3rd person shooters i've played. Overally it was kinda boring, but still worth the play.5/10 would pay 25cents to play an arcade game again
