Posted: December 9, 2014
 Curator-esque Review  More claustrophobic and linear than Red Faction: Guerrilla but still a fun game to play through solo.  Great effects, destruction, and cool tech make the short campaign enjoyable.  Red Faction: Armageddon Review (Spoiler Free)  Story A mysterious cult destroys the Terraformer, thus destabilizing Mars' atmosphere and driving most inhabitants on the planet underground.  Five years after these events, protagonist Darius finds mining work anyway he can, having left the Red Faction after their failed attempt to retake the Terraformer.  He accepts a contract from a group of shady Marauders and unwittingly releases an entombed alien race.  He is eventually ousted as the the one responsible and forced on the run.  Darius encounters old allies though as he runs and eventually begins the laborius task of driving the aliens back and finding the true identity of those who tricked him. Gameplay Armageddon is played in third-person similar to Guerrilla.  The campaign is single player only, but there is also an online co-op "horde mode" for up to four players and a sandbox/score attack destruction mode for you to fool around with solo.  Environmental destruction is one of the game's attractions.  At the start of the game, you are given a special tool that allows you to rebuild destroyed structures and objects.  Whereas a broken staircase in another game would prevent you from moving forward, in Armageddon you can literally rebuild the stairs.  Enemies can also make a mess of the environment.  A hulking alien can smash through every wall you put between you and it.  Tentacles will snatch fallen debris and throw it at you.  Destroying buildings is really fun just to watch them crumble.There is a a good variety of different weapons to use that destroy the environment in different ways.  Most of the time you will use these weapons to fight various classes of aliens.  Aliens frequently swarm you so your build tool also has some AOE attacks (such as a shield, anti-grav, and force-like push) to create some breathing room.  You will also get to pilot some pretty awesome vehicles.  The story plays out as you would expect it but what you'll be doing in each mission is highly varied.  The campaign never got dull for me and I was excited to play through it again on a harder difficulty.  Co-op is sparsely populated.  Although you can play it alone, it really is not as fun as the campaign. Design The aliens in Armageddon look amazing.  Their are multiple varieties of creepy crawlies each with their own color scheme, behavior, and on-screen effects.  All of them are very well animated.  Sound and lighting are also very nice, giving you the claustrophobic dread of being trapped in the dark underground.  All of the environments look nice too, whether they be vast caves, undeground towns, or surface camps in the middle of a lightning/sand storm.  Voice acting and cutscenes are great and the cast is alright for what the game is.  Music choice is appropriate though nothings really stood out to me. Final Thoughts Red Faction: Armageddon is a fun game to play through on your own a couple of times.  Fun gameplay, straightforward story, quality design, and environmental destruction are the reason to get this game.  Try to get it on sale if the short campaign and lack of multiplayer options deters you.  Can you find Mr. Toots?

												Mr. Mason, here's your gun and there're the bugs. Kill'em all and wipe out a few humans while you are at it. Cheers!That sums up what Red Faction: Armageddon is all about. It is an FPS-RPG game, with the FPS being very well done and the RPG complementing the game with power-ups, character abilities, and an excellent story. It is not an open-ended game, with a linear story and 'corridor' levels; in the sense that you can't just leave the main plot and go about exploring the world, ducking down this passage and that, rummaging in every nook and corner for hidden gems. Regardless, the story of the game is excellent and the action has been guided well by the developers. Every second has you desiring to know the next bit of the story. Your finger is always on the trigger, waiting to snap off a few rounds when the next alien appears from the shadows.Red Faction: Armageddon is fun and gripping. I would recommend it to all FPS lovers. On a final note, you can blow the environment to shreds. Cheers! God bless.

Posted: November 19, 2013
												I found this third person shooter a lot of fun. I've never played any of the other Red Factions, and am told that some of them (if not all) had a more open world feel compared to this much more linear adventure. However, I think its average metacritic score of 70 odd suffers from these sorts of comparisons, as it's a pretty enjoyable game in its own right without any previous experience with the rest of the franchise.There are a decent range of weapons that can float different people's boats, but I settled into my favourite four pretty quickly - the magnet gun, sniper rifle, mace (for up close and personal squishing), & a heavy damage weapon (which was the plasma cannon for a long time, rocket launcher, and then finally the singularity cannon). The best thing about the game however, is how much of the environment is destructable. It can break from enemy attack, your own attack, or you can even use it to harm enemies (particularly with the magnet gun). It's honestly one of the best features of the game, and using your particle repairer, you can build up most of the destroyed environment to destroy or throw at enemies again!Replayability may be a little sticking point however. Like I mentioned the single player is quite linear though can obviously be replayed. However, there are another two gamemodes, one of which can be multiplayer. The first is ruin which is essentially using all your best skills at destroying as much of the destructible environment in the map you're put on. There's a short time limit and points are earned on how much damage you do and at what efficiency. You essentially need to destroy X amount of points to complete the few different maps they have and can continue to try set bigger scores. However, it feels like just the addon it is rather than a completely different game mode. The second is Infestation, which is essentially defeating waves of enemies which get progressively harder (up to 20 waves per map). You can solo this or play with other people, with some similarities to that game mode in Gears of War. I'm not sure about whether or not you spawn more enemies when you play with other people compared to solo though (as I haven't played multiplayer), but I'd hope so given I was able to handle most things solo with just the magnet gun and a decent position on the map playing it smart. The better of the two additional gamemodes for sure, but only extends replayability a little bit more.Well worth the money I paid for it in a humble bundle. The entire red faction collection (which this game is included with) is still available both from the Humble store and here on steam (I think).

Posted: January 11, 2015
												Just finished my first run through the story.  It's a decent FPS with a twist: you can destroy most of the objects in the world.  Grab your magnet gun, tag a building then tag a group of bad guys and watch at the building is shredded into pieces and flies at the enemy!  Or tag an enemy and then tag a wall and watch them smash into the wall and die.One of the best parts of the original Red Faction was that everything was destructible, including the world.  Althought RF: Armageddon doesn't let you destroy the world, you can destroy pretty much everything in it.  You are also equipped with a nice tool called the Nanoforge which allows you to rebuild anything you busted up too (very useful for getting across those bridges you "accidentally" blew up)I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun FPS with interesting weapons.

Posted: January 11, 2015
												I say I would recommend this game with a hint of reluctance. It's a good game, storyline is good (but not great). The only thing that pisses me off is the combat system. I prefer an FPS in which everything dies more quickly, like Call of Juarez: Gunslinger (now THAT's a great game). I don't mean make the game easier, as I always like playing games on hardest mode. What I mean is, shooting the same god damn thing for ages waiting for it to dies gets boring after a while. Headshots don't seem to make much difference either. They could have made it so that enemies take much fewer hits to kill, and the protagonist is much easier to kill too (less health). Granted, you do get the sniper rifle which (when upgraded) gives you one shot kills, which is great. BUT you don't get the sniper until quite late on in the game. Also, because each enemy takes so many shots to kill, you often find yourself running out of ammo. Sure, there are ammo crates all over the place, but you can't hold that much ammo so I find myself running out of ammo whenever I'm faced with a big enemy that takes a lot of shots to kill.All in all, the fact that enemies take a lot of shots to kill, and that they usually quite fast and move around a lot, make the combat system a little bit annoying. Otherwise, not a bad game at all. I have tons of other FPS games to recommend instead of this one though.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												I was doubtful when I acquired this game through a one-time offer for 4.99$. I'm a fan of shoot'em-ups and specially sci-fi-based ones, but the comments I could read about the game were a mix of ups and downs.Now having reached 50% of the main campaign, I must say that technically the game's a beast. Gorgeous DX11 graphics, detailed characters and surroundings, awesome effects and explosions, impressive physics engine. The bugs are so detailed they'll scare you at times. I can't raise a single complain in this respect.However the designers screwd it up in one point: the difficulty level. Even in the highest difficulty level it's ridiculously easy to finish most stages, which combined with the strictly linear structure of the game turn what could be an awesome experience into a routine job. Switching weapons makes no sense due to this, since any weapon will do the job. When things could get a bit tougher you always find an armored battle suit or other mechanized help around. Moving from stage to stage is then a question of time and unless things change a lot in the second part of the game I think you can easily finish it within 20h of gameplay.This said, I think for 4.99$ it's a good buy. I really enjoy blowing away bugs and cultists at the same rate, tearing stuff apart, and of course the magnet gun. I think I might try to run through the game a second time limiting myself to flesh&bone and using just the magnet gun to make it more of a challenge.

												After beating the game on normal difficulty these are my conclusions:Pros:- nice graphics- nice (skippable) cinematics- weapon and vehicle variety (especially magnet gun and mallet)- special abilities- weapon and ability upgrades- environment destruction (and restoration)- pretty designed woman character :)- achievementsCons:- shallow and predictable storyline- meaningless dialogues- small variety of enemies- third person view- unsympathetic main character- linearity- achievements- the game crushes approx once in 2,5 hoursThis game is the fourth instalment of Red Faction series. I just played all of them for the first time and watched the movie in the last half a year. I was pretty amazed by the first one and was hoping the Armageddon would be like it with better graphics. But it wasn't! If you are younger or just this is the first game from the series you are going to play, you can end up with no interest in the series which would be a shame.I did not play a modern shooter in some years so I was pretty amazed by the graphics and cinematics (I just love the female character :)). The cinems are not disturbing and can be skipped. The linearity of the game is excessive. Places with different routes are common as rain on Sahara. It wouldn’t bother me so much if the environment variety would be higher. After 7 hours of play I was pretty bored and the idiotic main character was not helping. He is just a type of a superhero without a whit of intelligence. Just a stupid killing machine. I don't know how you, but I like a lot more first person shooters because you can feel much more immersed in the action. In difference with a sight on a mussle-idiot blocking my view.The weapons an abilities are good, maybe even the best things of the game not counting my beloved destruction :). For achievement hunters there are 58 achievs from which more than 60% can be done without trying on the first run but others are just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I am not interested in multiplayer and have no idea for now what the DLC is about, so no rating there.As a whole it is a pretty mediocre game and is not worth playing standalone and for the full price. Nothing spectacular here but a modern shooter with some fun guns and nice graphics. If you don't mind the old looks play the first Red Faction or the GTA styled Guerrilla destruction madness :).

content:
Posted: March 14
 Tell me what you are not and I will tell you what you are	Before getting into this you should be aware of what RF: Amrageddon is not.It is not an open world game. If you are looking for a continuation of RF: Guerilla than this is definitely not it. Armageddon is completely linear. Make sure you get this clear or else that's going ot be 2 hours of "I wonder when the map is going to open up" feelings.It is not open at all in fact. Pretty much the entire game happens in caves. Just caves caves and more caves. The environments are well crafted but way too same-ish to appeal to the eyes.It is not demolition paradise. Now whilst there are a few spectacular buildings to demolish, and the demolition physics are really sweet as usual with Red Faction, you can only fit that many types of building inside caves. No demolition derbys and challenges.So once you take all these things that made Red Faction games away from Armageddon, what is left?The answer is a pretty damn good shooter. The levels are (mostly) well balanced, enemy AI is effective, and most of all there are a ton of varied, whacky, or overpowered weapons to use. Flinging parts of buildings into giant insects with a magnet gun or detonating the (too few) buildings in the game with your remote charges is nothing short of awesome fun.  There are some short, but sweet, vehicle sections which add variety. The challenge level is just about right and outside a very annoying rail shooter bit near the start, I pretty enjoyed the whole thing from beginning to end without getting bored.Unfortunately the game is not bug-free. I encountered a few random crashes, could not alt tab without crashing, and most annoyingly the difficulty changed itself from hard to normal at some point during my campaign without me noticing.If you can overlook these shortcomings and know to expect something very different from the previous series, Armageddon is still worth playing to this date.

												This is a criminally underrated game. Again, because of the B-level of the Red Faction franchise as a whole, I suspect players and reviewers went into Armageddon already thinking it was going to suck. Well, that's the wrong expectation to have if you want to enjoy something, and, quite frankly, it doesn't suck. It just doesn't measure up to Guerilla, due to it being a linear Third Person Shooter that takes you to the opressive caverns beneath the surface of Mars. So, no, it's not better then Guerilla. It is, however, much better then Red Factions 1 and 2, and if you were engaged in Guerilla's plot and have seen the Origins film that ties these two games together, you will have sympathy for the Mason family and their plight, and will enjoy the game that much more. At a basic level, it has an array of satisfyingly destructive weaponry and even allows you to reconstruct destroyed buildings with the NanoForge device- so you can blow them up all over again. There's also co-op survival.

												To start, I greatly enjoyed the previous game Guerilla playing it twice through. Going into this game I expected a similiar fun experience with being able to demolish entire cities. That was my mistake. While I found this game extremely fun in itself, any fan or person thinking this is like the old ones, just hold the phone there and read what I have to say.Red Faction: Armageddon takes place almost entirely undergound, and unlike the very first Red Faction game, you cannot destroy the tunnel walls. This dispenses an atomosphere of restriction and lack of freedom, which compared to its' predecessors this game is restrictive. There are only a couple city-like places in the begginning that you can demolish and from there, you go undergound where there are just some structures you are allowed to destroy. Any old fan will be dissapointed. On top of that, the developers brought in a whole new aspect of aliens that you are fighting to save your existence. Personally, this doesn't bother me, but others may find this a turn off.Having said that, looking at this game as if it was its own series, it would be very fun. The destruction/rebuilding engine is still awesome in the limited amount you can use it, and it is just as fun as ever to clear your enemies using with the environment, like caving the roof of a shack in on a horde of aliens charging you. The upgrade system for your weapons and abilities was definitely one of my favorite parts. I felt the upgrades were noticable, which made me feel accomplished when I could afford them. They greatly change gamplay, making each players fighting style a bit different depending on how they go about upgrading. To wrap this up short and sweet:--Pros--The game is fun, featuring a moderately decent story. The mayham and methods of killing are where this game shines, allowing you to use your environment in fun and destructive ways, then rebuilding it (with the nano forge) and starting all over for the next wave of enemies, who you are already devising cunning new ways to splatter and break--cons -- I would not even bother comparing this to the old series, and many fans will be dissapointed if they buy this. IMPORTANT: This game does not allow for the free-roam that guerilla did, this was where most of my dissapoinment stems from.

												I've just finished playing this and wow. I bought this as a retail boxset of THQ games and this game is just fantastic. I haven't played any other Red Faction games, so I can't say how it fits with the story. But as an independent story its pretty neat - nothing too out of the ordinary however.The graphics are great, although you may become overwhelmed with particle effects at some of the more intense sections of the game. The voice acting and script are both convincing and help add a layer of immersion.The game handles fantastic - for those who played Saints Row The Third then RFA has exactly the same gun combat.There is a good variety of weapons including my favourite the magnet gun which allows you to kill the enemies using parts of the landscape. The repair tool that they give you also makes for an interesting gameplay mechanic requiring you to fix items in real time (difficult if you are faced with a few dozen enemies). You also get a selection of vehicles to use - which mixes things up.The only issues I have with this game is that it is quite short. It has the tendency to randomly quit the game for no reason. Enemies can spawn a few feet in front of you (not cool).

												The 4th in the Red Faction series, Armageddon seems to fall very short from what was just established a game before it. most of the terrain is destructable as you have come to expect from this series, but after a few chapters in the game even that becomes less than entertaining. While recreating broken items with your nanos is enjoyable, the level designs are regurgitated over and over and the enemy AI seems a bit off at times. This game features extra modes and difficulties to try and squeeze more interest from gamers, but over all other than fairly decent graphics and the ability to break everything in sight with a magnet gun or a rainbow farting pony, there isn't much to this game of monotomy. Worth a play if you are a fan, but not if this if your first romp on Mars.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I really wanted to enjoy this game, because I loved Guerilla so much. It manages to dissapoint completly. The gimmick of the Red Faction games has always beed destruction physics, and it is present in Armageddon as well. The problem is that Armageddon isnt about the destruction, unlike Guerilla. Armageddon is about shooting bugs, for the most part, there are some humans with bug helmets scattered around. The main issue i have with Armageddon is that the core gameplay is about shooting, whitch hasent gotten any better since Guerillas iffy gunplay, while the gimmick of destruction just demands as much attention as possible. I tried to make the most out of blowing things up to make buildings fall with enemies inside, or fall onto other buildings, but everything seems to be too far away or too short to do that with. In the first level I tried the hardest to do this, and sucssesfully knocked down one building. as the levels move forward, you will get a very strong sense of being pushed into a funnel, thats because they moved away from the open world to caves where your destroyed buildings will either get in the way or fall pitifully, making you remember that one time in Guerilla that you blew up a building and it covered the entire counrty. The nano forge is an interesting addition to the game, but isnt really something I think we needed. the nano forge is something that you can use to repair broken things in a radius around you, so you can remake cover, bridges, and other things. it could have an interesting use, but Ive never seen it. The nano forge seems to only be in the game so the designers could make stairs destructable without having to find a way to still get to the objective.I strongly reccomend giving this game a pass. If you want to get into the series, pick up Guerilla for the same price.If you wanted more of Guerilla, find a few friends to play the old multiplayer with, since its been put on steamworks now. If you were looking for more of Guerillas shooting in corridors, then this will be for you.

												You are Johnny McHammer, certified bald man who has an ancestor that was one of the CoD protagonists. Your awesome DNA is why the Space council entrusts you with the only crazy hammer on Mars, and a Magic wrist-mounted 3D printer that can print fireballs and all the houses you spent 5 minutes knocking down instead of fighting the alien cultists. Oh yeah, you also have to fight alien cultists who just want to kill everyone and everything on Mars because some old obscure Marvel supervillain/sithlord said they should.I think this game is very good, it is a refreshing take on 3rd person shooters in that your only weapon is the patented crazy hammer and 3D printer fireballs. It plays on this by sometimes giving you guns and you can't hit anything with them because you are in a 3rd person perspective and it would be really hard to aim a gun in real life if you saw everything like that. It is satire, ha ha, get it? The crazy hammer is crazy because you can destroy anything you want to with it, like there are houses with an enemy in it? Hit with hammer. This truly is a hidden gem in the 3rd person house-and-sometimes-skulls-obliterating-with-a-hammer genre.You don't even need to buy this game because it's already in your inventory and you won't even remember why.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												I really wanted to enjoy this game, because I loved Guerilla so much. It manages to dissapoint completly. The gimmick of the Red Faction games has always beed destruction physics, and it is present in Armageddon as well. The problem is that Armageddon isnt about the destruction, unlike Guerilla. Armageddon is about shooting bugs, for the most part, there are some humans with bug helmets scattered around. The main issue i have with Armageddon is that the core gameplay is about shooting, whitch hasent gotten any better since Guerillas iffy gunplay, while the gimmick of destruction just demands as much attention as possible. I tried to make the most out of blowing things up to make buildings fall with enemies inside, or fall onto other buildings, but everything seems to be too far away or too short to do that with. In the first level I tried the hardest to do this, and sucssesfully knocked down one building. as the levels move forward, you will get a very strong sense of being pushed into a funnel, thats because they moved away from the open world to caves where your destroyed buildings will either get in the way or fall pitifully, making you remember that one time in Guerilla that you blew up a building and it covered the entire counrty. The nano forge is an interesting addition to the game, but isnt really something I think we needed. the nano forge is something that you can use to repair broken things in a radius around you, so you can remake cover, bridges, and other things. it could have an interesting use, but Ive never seen it. The nano forge seems to only be in the game so the designers could make stairs destructable without having to find a way to still get to the objective.I strongly reccomend giving this game a pass. If you want to get into the series, pick up Guerilla for the same price.If you wanted more of Guerilla, find a few friends to play the old multiplayer with, since its been put on steamworks now. If you were looking for more of Guerillas shooting in corridors, then this will be for you.

Posted: April 14, 2013
												Red Faction: Bug Hunt is more in line with the original games than Guerilla was.  It's a linear story-focused experience that I found much more enjoyable than Guerilla.  It doesn't suffer from any of the drawbacks of that bland open world and has a much larger variety of gameplay experiences.The game has a wide variety of weapons, and they're all far more useful than anything in Guerilla.  The addition of the magnet gun is also fantastic, giving you another way to tear down buildings rather than burning through precious explosive ammo or slowly chipping away with a hammer.  There's even a gun that collects nearby debris and shoots it towards your enemies (in the DLC.)  This time around, only certain objects drop scrap when destroyed, but the upgrade systyem is much more robust allowing you to acquire and upgrade special nanoforge powers along with general upgrades.The destruction system is great fun like always, and feels improved since Guerilla, with buildings more realistically falling down when supports are destroyed rather than hanging in the air supported by one lone pillar.  In addition, you also have the ability to reconstruct destroyed objects.  Some people think this cheapens the destruction but I find it gives the level designers more options so they don't have to worry about whether you'll be able to continue after a structure is destroyed and also gives you more tactical options, being able to construct cover during combat.The graphics are quite good, and the game even has full DX11 support.  It even manages to run well even when buildings are exploding all around you.  Unfortunately the game uses an extremely low FOV, though it can be fixed by editing some game files as with all Volition games.The multiplayer is pretty fun, though I doubt you'll find anyone playing public games so it's best to bring friends.  There is a set of 8 survival maps, where you fight of waves of enemies to either survive, or defend key structures.  It shares upgrades with the single player so you'll have an easier time if you play the single player first.Overall a fantastic game and I hope Volition keeps working on Red Faction at their new home with Deep Silver.

												Mr. Mason, here's your gun and there're the bugs. Kill'em all and wipe out a few humans while you are at it. Cheers!That sums up what Red Faction: Armageddon is all about. It is an FPS-RPG game, with the FPS being very well done and the RPG complementing the game with power-ups, character abilities, and an excellent story. It is not an open-ended game, with a linear story and 'corridor' levels; in the sense that you can't just leave the main plot and go about exploring the world, ducking down this passage and that, rummaging in every nook and corner for hidden gems. Regardless, the story of the game is excellent and the action has been guided well by the developers. Every second has you desiring to know the next bit of the story. Your finger is always on the trigger, waiting to snap off a few rounds when the next alien appears from the shadows.Red Faction: Armageddon is fun and gripping. I would recommend it to all FPS lovers. On a final note, you can blow the environment to shreds. Cheers! God bless.

												First I have to say that I've played this game twice, and it was such a good overall experience I eventually plan to play it again.Red Faction : Armageddon separates itself from the previous Red Faction titles by moving from a first person shooter perspective to a third person shooter one. Otherwise, the game stays true to legacy of destructable environment that somewhat defined the franchise.The game includes nice additions, like the hammer and the power gauntlet, that allows you to feel like a techno-barbarian along with the cosy and warming feeling of being a futuristic soldier. It's really nice to mix close range battles with enemies you can shock, and your regular shotgun-rifle-sniper-rocket launcher cycle.The levels are varied and crafted enougth to deliver a good-to-great experience.Your character has some kind of a skill / buff tree in shape of several rings, so you can fine tune him to fit your play style. Anyhow, you'll end up with every one of them, so don't fear to make a mistake or forgot something crucial.The storyline is decent, and credible enougth to justify that level of rampage. Even if Red Faction : Armageddon will not blow your mind, it's a very good game that gives you a licence to blow every piece of man-made environment to the ground, and rebuild it with your nanobots if you feel it's the right thing to do.

												It has been a little bit since I last played this game (busy doing other things) so certain details may be a bit unspecific.Gameplay: 7/10The gameplay in this game is pretty standard for a third person shooter, however it adds an extra layer with a single feature. Near the beginning of the game, you are given a weapon that fires a magnet to one thing, then you can attach another magnet to something else and bring them together. This "Magnet Gun" is where the game shines the most (and lags the most depending on your computer). In Red Faction: Armageddon, the environments are almost completely destructible. There are some things you can't destroy, but it's amazing fun finding out what you can destory. Attach a magnet to a building and launch it towards a wall, squishing enemies along the way. Launch an enemy towards a wall and watch them go splat! The amount of destruction you can cause is amazing and satisfying. There are several guns you can pick up throughout the game, but I rarely used anything but magnets. Enemy around the corner? Magnet something in their direction and let physics take care of it. Enemy standing comedically close to a fall? Just thinking about those poor saps gives me vertigo. The best part about this destruction though is that so long as the destruction is not story required, you can use a machine to reverse time to build it again! Did I mention that the Magnet Gun has infinite ammo? Because it does! Unfortunately, as the Magnet Gun is possibly the best thing in the game, it's also why I have to dock a few point off of gameplay because of how all the other guns pale in comparison (especially the non-explosive ones). The game can be completed without picking up a single gun outside of the Magnet Gun and anything story-required.Story- 5/10I can't say too much about the story. As mentioned above "Gameplay", there are many details I do not remember as it's a been a while since I last played it. However, I feel I am somewhat good at remembering characters so long as I find them interesting. I found nearly nothing interesting about any of the characters. Your main character (whose name I can't even remember!) is very one-dimensional. He's the typical "I screwed up, life sucks for me, I screw up AGAIN and now I can redeem myself". There are nearly no plot twists I did not see coming and none of the moment I assume were meant to be sad really made me the least bit sad. I'm going to give a quick run down of how things set in motion, but if you feel like you want everything to be a surprise, consider this a "Spoiler Warning". Your character is part of the military on Mars I think (not sure) and are going to stop a bad dude who wants to ruin the civilizations that humans have built there. You learn about the game and move in to stop the bad guy. You find a wounded soldier who tells you where the bad guy went, where you then run into your commanding officer or whatever, but surprise! You and officer bro were the only ones in there! The wounded soldier WAS the bad guy and your character is an idiot. Bad guy wins and life goes downhill for people on Mars. Your character is now working in excavation for some reason and there's some chick (who I don't remember being mentioned beforehand) that knows your character and there is obvious lovey dovey stuff. Your character gets a job that pays well and all he has to do is break something! Sounds simple enough, right? Well it was! Destroy some stuff and go explore where this new hole in the floor you made goes, but surprise! The bad guy was sealed under the thing that anyone could've destroyed and now aliens are everywhere and your character is an idiot. I think he's even tried to redeem himself to his assumed girlfriend by saying "it payed well". Did it protagonist? I don't think they paid you a cent and I think your actually paying for this in guilt and ammunition. Unless you use the MAGNET GUN and it's INFINITE AMMO!Graphics-7/10I won't spend too much time here as I don't spend much time thinking about graphics (I'm more a Gameplay watcher) but from what I remember, the Graphics aren't too shabby. However, most of the game is dark which is very annoying in segments where you have to kill all the enemies in the area but it's too dark to see them. You have a radar that gives you a general location, but it isn't as helpful as you may think. In this game you fight against aliens, but the aliens, for the most part, are very agile and hard to hit as they jump around. Your radar could say you're right on top of them, but in reality, it is they who are on top of you. The darkness in this game makes for some frustrating moments when you want to find that one enemy you need to kill, but they're in the shadows above you and decide that if they shot you, you'd know where they are, which would give you a chance of winning.Enemies-5/10The enemies are very unoriginal and bland. None of enemies even talk save the bad guy from the beginning. You fight so many of the same enemies over and over again you start to figure out how far away the magnets would have to be to one-hit kill them. I played on Easy, but even so, the enemies were all easy to predict. Enemies only really ever got a hit on me when I was lagging from a building I launched at them. You have all the typical enemy types as well. You have the big bruisers that never flinch, the small bug things that are really only there to feel satisfying when you squish them under a rock you threw with you magnets, the fast and annoying ones, the ones that mess up your vision, the ones that spawn enemies and so on. Even the bad guy is very unoriginal and I can't even remember why. I think it had something to do with his people but I wasn't really interested in anything he said. At first, seeing new enemy types is exciting and you get to try out new tactics, but in the end, it loses the "Wow!" factor rather quickly and it seems more like a chore. The AI isn't much better either. As mentioned in Graphics, the AI and darkness make for a terrible combination because it's difficult to see enemies and they refuse to shoot you for reasons unknown. Have they had a change of heart? Are they planning on catching you off guard as you slowly go insane trying to find them? Did they run out of ammunition and are now to scared to come at you because they know they'll die? CAN they run out of ammo? No matter the reason, this usually boils down to using the magnets to launch anything and everything until they realize you've gone insane trying to find them, then go for the kill, only to be squished in your onlsauaght of rocks. The ragdoll physics are pretty hilarious though!Sense of Progression-6/10This game doesn't really feel like it gives you much in the way of feeling like you are actually doing something. There aren't very many guns in the game, character reveals don't really feel amazing, the plot twists couldn't even wring a towel and even the upgrade system is lacking! I don't remember how to upgrade, but I never even used it! I think there are items you collect like in Dead Space that you can use, but they are very generic upgrades that aren't even all that necessary! You have some kind of Force Push move that you can upgrade to make stun enemies, but the enemies are so stupid, they don't need to be stunned! They'll just stand still on their own! The game feels like it repeats itself and rarely mixes things up! You have very basic mission types that never actually add a twist and when you finally face something that isn't one of those bugs, you've already lost all sense of worry because of the AI!Overall-7/10The way I described the game may seem like it deserves less than a '7', but I still enjoyed the game quite a bit! I'm not one to ever hate a game and I find something appealing about the destructible environments. I can't say this is a game for everybody, but if you like Mass Effect, you may enjoy this game.

												You won't find this in any review but I very much thought this game was the peak of the series. It took them 4 games to create the engaging, visceral, destructive experience they were going for here and with the culmination of all of the lessons they have learnt, Violition has managed to create the most empowering third person shooter ever. Stasis in this game makes Isaac Clarke look like a noob, it not just stops enemies but drains their health and replenishes yours. The Mechs from F.E.A.R. were awesome? Nope, they cant quite charge through a wall, crush all the enemies in the way and cause the building they just went through to collapse. What's a gravity gun again? The Magnet gun is my favourite gun ever (along side the Portal Gun). This is the power-fantasy any crazy like me has been waiting for. Sniper shooting at you? Shoot a magnet at the base and another at the roof. The base flies upwards into the roof and the whole thing implodes and then collapses. Survive that! Boss fights consist of throwing the boss around the enviroment or pieces of the environment at them until they are impaled by debris and their body parts scatter with a gratifying splat. The campaign does get tedious towards the end though, with one long mission underground with no destructible environments and the story takes itself more seriously than I can. But Horde mode and a free form destroy everything 'Ruin Mode' provides some online fun. Valve better start working on Half Life 3 or everyone is just gonna rip off the old games and forget about them. R.I.P. Gravity Gun.

Posted: October 19, 2016
												(This review is just concerning the campaign and overall gameplay- not the multiplayer. I might also come back to edit this later)Honestly, this is a pretty mediocre game in my opinion. (Minor spoilers in second section)The presentation is good in places- though overall it lacks impact. Gameplay is linear; a 3rd person linear walk through dull and drab corridors. The color scheme is even more dull than Guerilla- having a lot of shades of gray and black. The art direction is awesome, and some of the designs are super, but all of the other aspects of the game, especially the color scheme, makes many of the designs unappealing. Some mechanics are cool, like the magnet gun, the nanoforge abilities + reconstructions, and using the mech (for the whole 2 or 3 times you can use it). The dynamic cover system from Guerilla is gone- though the havok engine is still there from Guerilla, which is cool. Aliens are there- but they are pretty meh. The third person camera sucks; it's so close to the character it becomes an eyesore less than halfway through the game- reducing awareness and reducing my interest in the game. Music is dull and is washed out- drowned in the incessant sounds of aliens, your own weaons, and the general cacaphony of overwhelming sound design. Horde mode is also there, which is an alright improvement. There are a few other modes- but the gameplay made me unintersted in playing these modes. The campaign is pretty cool though- fighting against crazy cultists is cool, and exploring the marauder cavern is cool. Fighting cultists in the storm was pretty cool. The bulk of the game is spent fighting aliens, but that is actually pretty dull- compared to the cultist sections. The main character is unappealing, and so are most of the other characters- their personalities being completely interchangable. Look, the point is: Buy Red Faction Guerilla. It's the same price, though it is more fun, and just overall more satisfying.Jeez dude, why do so many games insist on becoming dull and serious? Why can't we have nice things? Like another Red Faction Guerilla?

												I liked this Red Faction game the best other than the original Red Faction. The storyline integrates the original game's history and builds off of it to produce a compelling and interesting single player that kept me engaged all the way through the game. 												I was doubtful when I acquired this game through a one-time offer for 4.99$. I'm a fan of shoot'em-ups and specially sci-fi-based ones, but the comments I could read about the game were a mix of ups and downs.Now having reached 50% of the main campaign, I must say that technically the game's a beast. Gorgeous DX11 graphics, detailed characters and surroundings, awesome effects and explosions, impressive physics engine. The bugs are so detailed they'll scare you at times. I can't raise a single complain in this respect.However the designers screwd it up in one point: the difficulty level. Even in the highest difficulty level it's ridiculously easy to finish most stages, which combined with the strictly linear structure of the game turn what could be an awesome experience into a routine job. Switching weapons makes no sense due to this, since any weapon will do the job. When things could get a bit tougher you always find an armored battle suit or other mechanized help around. Moving from stage to stage is then a question of time and unless things change a lot in the second part of the game I think you can easily finish it within 20h of gameplay.This said, I think for 4.99$ it's a good buy. I really enjoy blowing away bugs and cultists at the same rate, tearing stuff apart, and of course the magnet gun. I think I might try to run through the game a second time limiting myself to flesh&bone and using just the magnet gun to make it more of a challenge.

												After beating the game on normal difficulty these are my conclusions:Pros:- nice graphics- nice (skippable) cinematics- weapon and vehicle variety (especially magnet gun and mallet)- special abilities- weapon and ability upgrades- environment destruction (and restoration)- pretty designed woman character :)- achievementsCons:- shallow and predictable storyline- meaningless dialogues- small variety of enemies- third person view- unsympathetic main character- linearity- achievements- the game crushes approx once in 2,5 hoursThis game is the fourth instalment of Red Faction series. I just played all of them for the first time and watched the movie in the last half a year. I was pretty amazed by the first one and was hoping the Armageddon would be like it with better graphics. But it wasn't! If you are younger or just this is the first game from the series you are going to play, you can end up with no interest in the series which would be a shame.I did not play a modern shooter in some years so I was pretty amazed by the graphics and cinematics (I just love the female character :)). The cinems are not disturbing and can be skipped. The linearity of the game is excessive. Places with different routes are common as rain on Sahara. It wouldn’t bother me so much if the environment variety would be higher. After 7 hours of play I was pretty bored and the idiotic main character was not helping. He is just a type of a superhero without a whit of intelligence. Just a stupid killing machine. I don't know how you, but I like a lot more first person shooters because you can feel much more immersed in the action. In difference with a sight on a mussle-idiot blocking my view.The weapons an abilities are good, maybe even the best things of the game not counting my beloved destruction :). For achievement hunters there are 58 achievs from which more than 60% can be done without trying on the first run but others are just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I am not interested in multiplayer and have no idea for now what the DLC is about, so no rating there.As a whole it is a pretty mediocre game and is not worth playing standalone and for the full price. Nothing spectacular here but a modern shooter with some fun guns and nice graphics. If you don't mind the old looks play the first Red Faction or the GTA styled Guerrilla destruction madness :).

												Taking inspiration from the mythos of many profound cultures, Red Faction: Armageddon uses the traditional "wheel" storytelling device as our hero ambles around mars for years until he returns to the source and brings enlightenment to his people. It is a triumph of moral thought and employs great use of cinematography and chiaroscuro lighting both in story and game. You have a gravity gun but it's bigger now and you can repair stuff, bringing peace and calm to the environment. There's 1 lady but she dies so it's okay. 9/10

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Red Faction Armageddon looks great in DX11, and I had little to no performance issues whatsoever. I did however have audio problems (had to switch to stereo over surround) and occasionally at cutscenes the game would crash. Other than that this game is great. One downfall of this game is that it relies too heavily on drowning the player in aliens, making it near impossible to shoot everything. Luckily when playing on normal mode you're nearly indestructable, so the hordes you face aren't so daunting.This game has just the right amount of upgrades and the menus are simple and straightforward. When you beat the game you also unlock one of the most badass weapons possible, Mr. Toots.Overall I'd give this game an 8/10, the only bad part was the immense audio problems - maybe its not really worth 50$ though, so wait for a sale ;)

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I've just finished playing this and wow. I bought this as a retail boxset of THQ games and this game is just fantastic. I haven't played any other Red Faction games, so I can't say how it fits with the story. But as an independent story its pretty neat - nothing too out of the ordinary however.The graphics are great, although you may become overwhelmed with particle effects at some of the more intense sections of the game. The voice acting and script are both convincing and help add a layer of immersion.The game handles fantastic - for those who played Saints Row The Third then RFA has exactly the same gun combat.There is a good variety of weapons including my favourite the magnet gun which allows you to kill the enemies using parts of the landscape. The repair tool that they give you also makes for an interesting gameplay mechanic requiring you to fix items in real time (difficult if you are faced with a few dozen enemies). You also get a selection of vehicles to use - which mixes things up.The only issues I have with this game is that it is quite short. It has the tendency to randomly quit the game for no reason. Enemies can spawn a few feet in front of you (not cool).

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Few years ago, I bought myself a copy of Red Faction: Guerrilla, mainly because I liked the concept - GTA where instead of kicking everyone's butt all the time you pulverize everyone's property all the time. After I've finished it, I felt both happy and sad - happy because the money was worth the millions of dollars of property damage I've so carelessly caused, and sad because half of my play time was just trying to get from point A to point B to start a really short mission, aand after that spending the same time trying to get to the next mission. And honestly, that was sooo boring.So, after I've seen a review saying really nice things about this game, I couldn't resist and I spent yet another ten bucks on this game. And the first thing I realised was that this was GTA no more. No, the game presents us pretty linear, straight (but nice) levels. And the change is perfect. This game is swift, action-packed, and mostly much more hillarious. I don't remember a single moment from RF: Guerrilla that was somehow funny, which is something I like about games (being funny). And this game? At one particular joke, I fell off my chair, choking of laughter. No really, aside from a lot better gameplay, this game is so much fun to play that can't stop doing so.Verdict? 9,5/10, I just miss the freedom that I had in RF: Guerrilla (but then again, here the freedom was changed fo a lot better game, and a destruction-bringing Unicorn).
